Sentences_from: -- Ta ścieżka prowadzi do Merripit-House -- rzekł Stapleton. -- Może mnie pan zechce zaszczycić swojemi odwiedzinami?
Sentences_to: "A moderate walk along this moor-path brings us to Merripit House," said he. "Perhaps you will spare an hour that I may have the pleasure of introducing you to my sister."
Translated_sentences: -"This path leads to merripit-House," said Stapleton. -- Would you like to honor me with a visit?

Sentences_from: Przypuśćmy, że jest tam jakiś pies zdziczały -- byłoby to wyjaśnieniem tych wszystkich zagadek. Lecz gdzież taki pies ukrywa się?
Sentences_to: He is no one whom I have seen down here, and I have now met all the neighbours.
Translated_sentences: Suppose there's a feral dog in there -- that would explain all the riddles. But where does such a dog hide?

Sentences_from: -- Wolałbym, żebyś mi to opowiedział żywem słowem.
Sentences_to: "Perhaps you would kindly give me a sketch of the course of events from memory."
Translated_sentences: -- I'd rather you tell me that in real life.

Sentences_from: -- To jednak dziwne! -- zauważył doktor Mortimer. -- Przeszukałem starannie cały pokój przed śniadaniem...
Sentences_to: "But it is a very singular thing," Dr. Mortimer remarked. "I searched this room carefully before lunch."
Translated_sentences: -- That's weird! -- Dr. Mortimer noted. -- I searched the room thoroughly before breakfast...

Sentences_from: Przez pół godziny czekałem w natężeniu, ale oprócz płaczu nie usłyszałem nic zgoła.
Sentences_to: The noise could not have been far away and was certainly in the house. For half an hour I waited with every nerve on the alert, but there came no other sound save the chiming clock and the rustle of the ivy on the wall.
Translated_sentences: For half an hour I waited in intensity, but apart from crying I heard nothing at all.

Sentences_from: -- Kiedy się dowiedziałeś o przebywaniu drugiego człowieka na bagnie?
Sentences_to: "Excellent, Watson! And how did you localize me?
Translated_sentences: - When did you find out about the other man in the swamp?

Sentences_from: Należało odjąć wizycie wszelki charakter uroczysty.
Sentences_to: The more formal we made the visit the less information we might obtain.
Translated_sentences: It was necessary to subtract from the visit any ceremonial character.

Sentences_from: Zaczynam więc od dnia, następującego po tym, w którym wykryłem dwa bardzo ważne fakty: a więc naprzód, że pani Laura Lyons z Coombe-Tracey pisała do sir Karola Baskerville i wyznaczyła mu spotkanie o godzinie, w której śmierć znalazł; powtóre, że człowiek, przebywający na bagnie, ukrywa się w jednej z jaskiń na stoku góry.
Sentences_to: I start then from the day which succeeded that upon which I had established two facts of great importance, the one that Mrs. Laura Lyons of Coombe Tracey had written to Sir Charles Baskerville and made an appointment with him at the very place and hour that he met his death, the other that the lurking man upon the moor was to be found among the stone huts upon the hill-side.
Translated_sentences: I begin, therefore, on the day following that in which I discovered two very important facts: that Mrs. Laura Lyons, of Coombe-Tracey, wrote to Sir Charles Baskerville, and appointed him to meet at the hour at which he found his death; that, again, the man who was in the swamp was hiding in one of the caves on the side of the mountain.

Sentences_from: U stóp naszych leżało olbrzymia psisko, wielkości młodej lwicy; był to mieszaniec wyżła i brytana.
Sentences_to: In mere size and strength it was a terrible creature which was lying stretched before us. It was not a pure bloodhound and it was not a pure mastiff; but it appeared to be a combination of the two--gaunt, savage, and as large as a small lioness.
Translated_sentences: At our feet lay a huge dog, the size of a young lioness; it was a mixture of a Highland and a Briton.

Sentences_from: Mówię to, żeby panu ułatwić rozwiązanie zagadki, nad którą pan zastanawiał się, patrząc na oparzeliska.
Sentences_to: All this, Dr. Watson, has been brought upon your head by your expression as you surveyed the moor out of our window."
Translated_sentences: I'm saying this to make it easier for you to solve the riddle you've been puzzling over as you've looked at the burns.

Sentences_from: -- Jesteś w błędzie co do jego fachu.
Sentences_to: "Surely you are mistaken about his trade?"
Translated_sentences: -- You're wrong about his expertise.

Sentences_from: Maść w tej oto blaszance jest zapewne mieszaninę siarki i fosforu, którą pies był wysmarowany.
Sentences_to: On an emergency he could keep the hound in the out-house at Merripit, but it was always a risk, and it was only on the supreme day, which he regarded as the end of all his efforts, that he dared do it.
Translated_sentences: The ointment in this tin is probably a mixture of sulfur and phosphorus, which the dog was greased.

Sentences_from: -- Nazywa się Seldon. Wpakowano go do więzienia za morderstwo w Notting-Hill.
Sentences_to: "It is Selden, the Notting Hill murderer."
Translated_sentences: -- His name is Seldon. He was sent to prison for murder in Notting Hill.

Sentences_from: -- Czemuż więc nie uprzedziłaś pani o tem sir Karola?
Sentences_to: "Why then, did you not write to Sir Charles and explain this?"
Translated_sentences: -- Then why didn't you tell Sir Charles?

Sentences_from: -- O ile można przypuszczać, te słowa zostały wycięte scyzorykiem.
Sentences_to: "So far as I can follow you, then, Mr. Holmes," said Sir Henry Baskerville, "someone cut out this message with a scissors--"
Translated_sentences: - As far as I can tell, those words were cut out with a penknife.

Sentences_from: Wróciłem do moich towarzyszów, aby zdać raport Holmesowi.
Sentences_to: "You say, Watson, that the lady is not there?" Holmes asked, when I had finished my report.
Translated_sentences: I went back to my comrades to report to Holmes.

Sentences_from: Ręczę panu za to słowem honoru.
Sentences_to: But he will never trouble anyone in this country again.
Translated_sentences: I give you my word of honor for that.

Sentences_from: Odrzekła mi na to bez namysłu:
Sentences_to: She met my difficulty with the utmost readiness.
Translated_sentences: She said it to me without thinking.:

Sentences_from: Księżyc w pełni zachodził za jedną z wyższych skał; wtem na jej szczycie ujrzałem postać męską, wyglądającą jak posąg.
Sentences_to: The moon was low upon the right, and the jagged pinnacle of a granite tor stood up against the lower curve of its silver disc.
Translated_sentences: The moon was fully setting behind one of the higher rocks, and at the top of it I saw a male figure that looked like a statue.

Sentences_from: „Otóż ów Hugon pokochał (jeśli można tem mianem nazwać tak dzikie uczucie), pokochał zatem córkę czynszownika, dzierżawiącego grunta w pobliżu dóbr Baskerville.
Sentences_to: This, in truth, his neighbours might have pardoned, seeing that saints have never flourished in those parts, but there was in him a certain wanton and cruel humour which made his name a byword through the West.
Translated_sentences: "Now this Hugon loved (if such a wild feeling can be called), so he loved the daughter of a tenant who leased land near the Baskerville estate.

Sentences_from: Nasz baronet zaczyna interesować się żywo piękną sąsiadką.
Sentences_to: The fact is that our friend, the baronet, begins to display a considerable interest in our fair neighbour.
Translated_sentences: Our baronet is beginning to take a keen interest in our beautiful neighbour.

Sentences_from: Jak wryty w ziemię, stał żołnierz na koniu, z bagnetem przez ramię.
Sentences_to: A steep curve of heath-clad land, an outlying spur of the moor, lay in front of us. On the summit, hard and clear like an equestrian statue upon its pedestal, was a mounted soldier, dark and stern, his rifle poised ready over his forearm. He was watching the road along which we travelled.
Translated_sentences: As if buried in the ground, stood a soldier on horseback, with a bayonet over his shoulder.

Sentences_from: Gdybyż tylko na tem poprzestał! ale on chce podobno wytoczyć proces doktorowi Mortimer za otwarcie grobu przedhistorycznego bez pozwolenia potomków, a to skutkiem... czaszki z epoki neolitycznej, odgrzebanej w Long-Dawn.
Sentences_to: If he would confine his energies to this all would be well, but there are rumours that he intends to prosecute Dr. Mortimer for opening a grave without the consent of the next-of-kin, because he dug up the Neolithic skull in the barrow on Long Down.
Translated_sentences: If only he'd stop! but he's supposedly going to sue Dr. Mortimer for opening a prehistoric grave without permission from the descendants, and with effect... skulls from the Neolithic era, excavated at long-dawn.

Sentences_from: Kamerdyner przyniósł mi kawę do biblioteki; skorzystałem z tego, aby mu zadać parę pytań.
Sentences_to: The butler brought me my coffee into the library, and I took the chance to ask him a few questions.
Translated_sentences: The Butler brought me coffee to the library; I used it to ask him a few questions.

Sentences_from: Przykro mi, że się panu narzucam, ale nie mogę puścić pana samego na trzęsawiska.
Sentences_to: I am sorry to intrude, but you heard how earnestly Holmes insisted that I should not leave you, and especially that you should not go alone upon the moor."
Translated_sentences: I'm sorry to impose on you, but I can't let you go to the quagmire alone.

Sentences_from: -- Gdybyś nam się zwierzył z własnej i nieprzymuszonej woli, byłaby rzecz inna -- przekładał mu baronet -- ale powiedziałeś nam, a właściwie twoja żona powiedziała nam prawdę pod naciskiem, więc mamy ręce rozwiązane.
Sentences_to: "If you had told us of your own free will it would have been a different thing," said the baronet, "you only told us, or rather your wife only told us, when it was forced from you and you could not help yourself."
Translated_sentences: -"If you had confided in us of your own free will, it would have been different," the baronet told him, " but you told us, and in fact your wife told us the truth under duress, so our hands are tied.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne to pytanie... -- rzekła, udając obrażoną.
Sentences_to: "Really, sir, this is a very extraordinary question."
Translated_sentences: -- That's a weird question... -- she said, pretending to be offended.

Sentences_from: W oczach wszystkich ów zbrodniarz był potworem i wyrzutkiem społeczeństwa; ona widziała w nim zawsze chłopaka z jasnymi kędziorami, którego nosiła na ręku i kochała, jak własne dziecko.
Sentences_to: To all the world he was the man of violence, half animal and half demon; but to her he always remained the little wilful boy of her own girlhood, the child who had clung to her hand.
Translated_sentences: In the eyes of all, this criminal was a monster and an outcast of society; she always saw in him a boy with light curls, whom she carried on her arm and loved like her own child.

Sentences_from: Holmes, patrząc na trupa, śmiał się, ręce zacierał.
Sentences_to: He had uttered a cry and bent over the body. Now he was dancing and laughing and wringing my hand.
Translated_sentences: Holmes, looking at the corpse, laughed, rubbed his hands.

Sentences_from: Mój przyjaciel i ja jesteśmy w zbrojnem pogotowiu.
Sentences_to: My friend and I are also ready for emergencies."
Translated_sentences: My friend and I are on armed alert.

Sentences_from: Miałem tylko trzy pary: nowe żółte, stare czarne i te oto lakierki. Wczoraj zniknął jeden od żółtej pary, a dziś jeden od czarnej.
Sentences_to: "What! you don't mean to say----?"
Translated_sentences: I only had three pairs: the new yellow, the old black, and these varnishes. Yesterday, one disappeared from a yellow couple, and today, one from a black one.

Sentences_from: Noc była tak ciemna, że przy najlepszym wzroku niepodobna było nic dojrzeć.
Sentences_to: The man is a striking-looking fellow, very well equipped to steal the heart of a country girl, so that this theory seemed to have something to support it. That opening of the door which I had heard after I had returned to my room might mean that he had gone out to keep some clandestine appointment.
Translated_sentences: The night was so dark that with the best of eyesight it was impossible to see anything.

Sentences_from: Wszak pan, sir Henryku, opuściłeś Baskerville-Hall w bardzo młodym wieku?
Sentences_to: But you were very young when you last saw Baskerville Hall, were you not?"
Translated_sentences: After all, Sir Henry, you left Baskerville Hall at a very young age?

Sentences_from: Mieszka o cztery mile od nas.
Sentences_to: He is an elderly man, red-faced, white-haired, and choleric.
Translated_sentences: He lives four miles from us.

Sentences_from: Pożądanem jest, aby spadkobierca sir Karola mógł objąć jaknajprędzej majątek i prowadzić dalej chlubną działalność, przerwaną tak nagle i tak tragicznie. „Gdyby prozaiczne orzeczenie sędziego śledczego i rzeczoznawców nie położyło końca romantycznym historyom, krążącym na temat owej śmierci, nie łatwo byłoby znaleźć właściciela Baskerville Hall.
Sentences_to: I had observed some newspaper comment at the time, but I was exceedingly preoccupied by that little affair of the Vatican cameos, and in my anxiety to oblige the Pope I lost touch with several interesting English cases.
Translated_sentences: It is desirable that the heir of Sir Charles should be able to take possession of the estate as soon as possible, and to carry on the laudable business which has been so suddenly and so tragically interrupted. "If the prosaic ruling of the investigating judge and appraisers had not put an end to the romantic stories circulating about this death, it would not have been easy to find the owner of Baskerville Hall.

Sentences_from: Widuję chłopaka z zawiniątkiem codziennie, a czasem dwa razy na dzień. Poczekaj pan chwilkę.
Sentences_to: I have seen the boy again and again with his bundle. Every day, and sometimes twice a day, I have been able--but wait a moment, Dr. Watson.
Translated_sentences: I see a guy with a wrap every day, sometimes twice a day. Wait a minute, sir.

Sentences_from: Przez chwilę stałem z kartką w ręku, nie rozumiejąc, co znaczy to uwiadomienie.
Sentences_to: For a minute I stood there with the paper in my hands thinking out the meaning of this curt message. It was I, then, and not Sir Henry, who was being dogged by this secret man.
Translated_sentences: I stood for a moment with the note in my hand, not understanding what this notice meant.

Sentences_from: -- Masz swoje pół suwerena; dostaniesz drugie pół, jak mi doniesiesz coś więcej.
Sentences_to: "Well, then, here is your half-sovereign. There's another one waiting for you if you can bring any more information.
Translated_sentences: -- You have your half sovereign; you'll get the other half if you tell me more.

Sentences_from: -- Za każdym razem portyer, stojący we drzwiach, wezwie portyera, siedzącego w sieni -- i temu dasz po szylingu.
Sentences_to: "In each case the outside porter will send for the hall porter, to whom also you will give a shilling.
Translated_sentences: -- Every time portyer, standing in the door, calls portyer, sitting in the hall -- and you give him a shilling.

Sentences_from: Z wagonu pierwszej klasy wyskoczył mężczyzna krępy, o twarzy wesołej.
Sentences_to: We all three shook hands, and I saw at once from the reverential way in which Lestrade gazed at my companion that he had learned a good deal since the days when they had first worked together.
Translated_sentences: A stocky, cheerful-looking man jumped out of a first-class carriage.

Sentences_from: Czyżby on pozwalał sir Henrykowi starać się o własną żonę...
Sentences_to: Are you sure of what you say? How could he have permitted Sir Henry to fall in love with her?"
Translated_sentences: Did he allow Sir Henry to seek his own wife?..

Sentences_from: Stąpał powoli, zakradał się jakby, wreszcie stanął u drzwi bocznej oficyny.
Sentences_to: Looking over, I saw the naturalist pause at the door of an out-house in the corner of the orchard.
Translated_sentences: He walked slowly, crept as if, finally stood at the door of the side office.

Sentences_from: Czy i teraz, łotrze, będziesz przeczył, że dawaliście sobie sygnały?...
Sentences_to: Now, you rascal, do you deny that it is a signal?
Translated_sentences: And now, villain, will you deny that you gave each other signals?...

Sentences_from: Pierwszą myślą Stapletona było zapewne zgładzić go ze świata w Londynie.
Sentences_to: "It is possible that Stapleton did not know of the existence of an heir in Canada. In any case he would very soon learn it from his friend Dr. Mortimer, and he was told by the latter all details about the arrival of Henry Baskerville.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton's first thought was probably to exterminate him from the world in London.

Sentences_from: Ten sam jęk powtórzył się bliżej, dźwięczał w nim strach i ból.
Sentences_to: The cry had been loud on account of its vehemence, but it had pealed out from somewhere far off on the shadowy plain. Now it burst upon our ears, nearer, louder, more urgent than before.
Translated_sentences: The same moan came closer, filled with fear and pain.

Sentences_from: -- Tak; po obu stronach biegnie trawnik, szerokości 6 stóp.
Sentences_to: "Yes, there is a strip of grass about six feet broad on either side."
Translated_sentences: -- Yes; there's a lawn on both sides, six feet wide.

Sentences_from: -- Oboje z żoną otrzymali po pięćset funtów.
Sentences_to: "He and his wife had five hundred pounds each."
Translated_sentences: - He and his wife each received 500 pounds.

Sentences_from: Nie sądziłem, że pan masz czas oddawać się takim zamiłowaniom...
Sentences_to: I didn't know that you found time for such things."
Translated_sentences: I didn't think you had time to indulge in such passions...

Sentences_from: Sherlock miał niezwykły dar zwracania dowolnie swoich myśli w jakimbądź kierunku.
Sentences_to: Sherlock Holmes had, in a very remarkable degree, the power of detaching his mind at will.
Translated_sentences: Sherlock had a remarkable gift for turning his thoughts in any direction.

Sentences_from: Dla tych dwóch powodów nie zeznałem przed sądem wszystkiego, co wiem -- albowiem nie zdałoby się to na nic sędziemu śledczemu -- ale z panem będę zupełnie szczery.
Sentences_to: For both these reasons I thought that I was justified in telling rather less than I knew, since no practical good could result from it, but with you there is no reason why I should not be perfectly frank.
Translated_sentences: For those two reasons, I haven't given the court everything I know -- because it wouldn't have mattered to the investigating judge -- but I'll be completely honest with you.

Sentences_from: Policya płaci dobrze za wiadomości o zbiegach. Można zarobić kilka funtów.
Sentences_to: "Well, I understand that they get five pounds if they can give information."
Translated_sentences: Policya pays well for news of fugitives. You can earn a few pounds.

Sentences_from: Już Barrymore mówił mi, że nieznajomego obsługuje chłopak.
Sentences_to: It was on his track, and not upon the convict's, that Frankland had stumbled.
Translated_sentences: Barrymore already told me that a stranger was being served by a boy.

Sentences_from: Gdybyś pani była niewinną, to w pierwszej chwili nie zaprzeczyłabyś, żeś pisała tego dnia do sir Karola.
Sentences_to: If your position is innocent, why did you in the first instance deny having written to Sir Charles upon that date?"
Translated_sentences: If you were innocent, you wouldn't deny at first that you wrote to Sir Charles that day.

Sentences_from: Otworzył nam drzwi stary, mrukliwy służący.
Sentences_to: We were admitted by a strange, wizened, rusty-coated old manservant, who seemed in keeping with the house.
Translated_sentences: The door was opened for us by an old, grumpy servant.

Sentences_from: Wszak macie tu posługacza nazwiskiem Cartridge, który wykazał dużo sprytu podczas śledztwa.
Sentences_to: I have some recollection, Wilson, that you had among your boys a lad named Cartwright, who showed some ability during the investigation."
Translated_sentences: After all, you have here a man named Cartridge, who has shown a lot of cunning in the course of his investigation.

Sentences_from: Oczy jej pałały, nóżka uderzała o ziemię.
Sentences_to: Her eyes blazed at me, and she tapped the ground impatiently with her foot.
Translated_sentences: Her eyes were burning, her foot was hitting the ground.

Sentences_from: -- Czy nie należałoby przedewszystkiem pozbyć się małżonków Barrymore?
Sentences_to: "Would it not be well in the first place to get rid of this Barrymore couple?"
Translated_sentences: -- Wouldn't it be better to get rid of Barrymore's spouses first?

Sentences_from: Człowiek przedhistoryczny zaludniał gęsto te bagna, a ponieważ od tych czasów nikt tu nie mieszkał, ich jaskinie pozostały nietknięte.
Sentences_to: Prehistoric man lived thickly on the moor, and as no one in particular has lived there since, we find all his little arrangements exactly as he left them. These are his wigwams with the roofs off.
Translated_sentences: Prehistoric man densely populated these swamps, and since no one has lived here since then, their caves remained intact.

Sentences_from: -- Doniesiono mi z policyi, że ktoś, mieszkający pod tym adresem, wypytuje o Nr. 2704 -- rzekł ów człowiek o twarzy dobrodusznej. -- Jeżdżę już siedem lat i nikt na mnie nigdy skargi nie wnosił, więc bardzo mnie to zadziwiło i przyjechałem, żeby się dowiedzieć, co pan ma przeciwko mnie.
Sentences_to: "I got a message from the head office that a gent at this address had been inquiring for 2704," said he. "I've driven my cab this seven years and never a word of complaint. I came here straight from the Yard to ask you to your face what you had against me."
Translated_sentences: -"I have been informed by the police that someone living at this address is asking for number 2704," said the man with the good-natured face. -- I've been driving for seven years and no one has ever complained about me, so I was very surprised, and I came here to find out what you have against me.

Sentences_from: -- Czyżeś pan nie oglądał ziemi dokoła?
Sentences_to: "Good heaven! Did no one examine?"
Translated_sentences: -- Haven't you been looking around?

Sentences_from: Dziki zwierz biegł śladami naszego przyjaciela w podskokach...
Sentences_to: "Hist!" cried Holmes, and I heard the sharp click of a cocking pistol. "Look out! It's coming!"
Translated_sentences: The wild animal followed in our friend's footsteps in the jumps...

Sentences_from: Wahał się, jak gdyby żałował swego odezwania, lub nie mógł znaleźć słów do wyrażenia myśli.
Sentences_to: Barrymore hesitated for a moment, as if he regretted his outburst, or found it difficult to express his own feelings in words.
Translated_sentences: He hesitated, as if he regretted his words, or could not find the words to express his thoughts.

Sentences_from: Zbrodniarz zaklął przeraźliwie i zrzucił ogromny kamień. Roztrzaskał się on o skałę, o którą opieraliśmy się przed chwilą.
Sentences_to: At the same moment the convict screamed out a curse at us and hurled a rock which splintered up against the boulder which had sheltered us.
Translated_sentences: The criminal cursed in horror and threw a huge stone. It shattered against the rock we were leaning against.

Sentences_from: Ma obecnie siedem procesów, które zapewne pochłoną resztę jego fortuny. Po za tą manią wydaje się dobrodusznym, poczciwym staruszkiem; wspominam o nim dlatego tylko, żeś mi polecił opisywać ci wszystkie osoby, które spotykam i o których słyszę.
Sentences_to: He is said to have about seven lawsuits upon his hands at present, which will probably swallow up the remainder of his fortune and so draw his sting and leave him harmless for the future. Apart from the law he seems a kindly, good-natured person, and I only mention him because you were particular that I should send some description of the people who surround us.
Translated_sentences: He now has seven trials that will probably consume the rest of his fortune. After all this mania, he seems like a good-natured, honest old man; I mention him only because you instructed me to describe to you all the people I meet and hear about.

Sentences_from: -- Spostrzegłem to odrazu, gdyś pan wszedł do pokoju -- odparł Holmes.
Sentences_to: "I observed it as you entered the room," said Holmes.
Translated_sentences: -"I saw it when you came into the room," said Holmes.

Sentences_from: -- Jak widzę, pamiętasz, Wilson, drobną przysługę, którą miałem sposobność ci wyświadczyć -- rzekł mój przyjaciel.
Sentences_to: "Ah, Wilson, I see you have not forgotten the little case in which I had the good fortune to help you?"
Translated_sentences: -"I see you remember, Wilson, a little favor I had occasion to do you," said my friend.

Sentences_from: Odwróciłem się, pewien, że ujrzę doktora Mortimer, lecz ku mojemu zdziwieniu, zobaczyłem nieznajomego. Był to mężczyzna niewielkiego wzrostu, o twarzy wygolonej, o włosach ciemnych, gładko przyczesanych; mógł mieć lat trzydzieści parę do czterdziestu.
Sentences_to: "Your net and box would have told me as much," said I, "for I knew that Mr. Stapleton was a naturalist.
Translated_sentences: I turned, sure I'd see Dr. Mortimer, but to my surprise, I saw a stranger. He was a man of small stature, with a shaven face, dark hair, neatly combed; he could have been between thirty and forty years old.

Sentences_from: Minęliśmy ciemną aleję, i szerokim, wzniesionym podjazdem zajechaliśmy przed pałac. Środkowy korpus ozdobiony był wspaniałym portykiem; po bokach wznosiły się wieże, średniowieczne, zębate, ze strzelnicami.
Sentences_to: The avenue opened into a broad expanse of turf, and the house lay before us. In the fading light I could see that the centre was a heavy block of building from which a porch projected. The whole front was draped in ivy, with a patch clipped bare here and there where a window or a coat-of-arms broke through the dark veil. >From this central block rose the twin towers, ancient, crenelated, and pierced with many loopholes. To right and left of the turrets were more modern wings of black granite. A dull light shone through heavy mullioned windows, and from the high chimneys which rose from the steep, high-angled roof there sprang a single black column of smoke.
Translated_sentences: We passed a dark alley, and a wide, elevated driveway pulled up in front of the palace. The central body was decorated with a magnificent portico; on the sides towers rose, medieval, toothed, with shooting galleries.

Sentences_from: Jak wielu mądrych zbrodniarzy, jest zapewne zbyt zaufany w swoim rozumie i wyobraża sobie, że nas w pole wywiedzie.
Sentences_to: Like most clever criminals, he may be too confident in his own cleverness and imagine that he has completely deceived us."
Translated_sentences: Like a lot of smart criminals, he's probably overconfident in his understanding and imagines he'll lead us into the field.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk i doktor Mortimer bawili w Londynie, gotując się do dalekiej podróży, która miała wzmocnić nerwy baroneta.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer were, however, in London, on their way to that long voyage which had been recommended for the restoration of his shattered nerves. They had called upon us that very afternoon, so that it was natural that the subject should come up for discussion.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer were playing in London, preparing for a long journey to strengthen the baronet's nerves.

Sentences_from: Dom, przerobiony widocznie ze starej fermy, wznosił się wśród drzew niewielkich, otoczony był murowanym parkanom; wyglądał smutno i ponuro.
Sentences_to: An orchard surrounded it, but the trees, as is usual upon the moor, were stunted and nipped, and the effect of the whole place was mean and melancholy.
Translated_sentences: The house, apparently converted from an old farm, rose among small trees, was surrounded by a brick fence; it looked sad and gloomy.

Sentences_from: -- Ha! nie jest to miła robota, zwłaszcza wśród takiego otoczenia. Cóż za pustkowie!... -- mówił Lestrade, oglądając się dokoła.
Sentences_to: "My word, it does not seem a very cheerful place," said the detective with a shiver, glancing round him at the gloomy slopes of the hill and at the huge lake of fog which lay over the Grimpen Mire. "I see the lights of a house ahead of us."
Translated_sentences: -- Ha! it's not a nice job, especially in this environment. What a wasteland!... -- said Lestrade, looking around.

Sentences_from: Oto i wszystko, co wiem o tej ciekawej sprawie.
Sentences_to: "No doubt. There only remains one difficulty.
Translated_sentences: That's all I know about this interesting case.

Sentences_from: Czy wolno mi zapytać, kto jest pierwszym?
Sentences_to: May I inquire who has the honour to be the first?" asked Holmes with some asperity.
Translated_sentences: May I ask who goes first?

Sentences_from: -- A więc poproszę pana, abyś słuchał mnie ślepo.
Sentences_to: "Very good; and I will ask you also to do it blindly, without always asking the reason."
Translated_sentences: -- Then I'll ask you to listen to me blindly.

Sentences_from: -- Ho, ho! mój chłopcze, źle się domyślasz. Słyszałeś zapewne o zbiegu, ukrywającym się na bagnie?
Sentences_to: "Ha, ha, my boy, a very much more important matter than that!
Translated_sentences: -- Ho, ho! my boy, you're wrong. You heard about the fugitive hiding out in the swamp?

Sentences_from: -- Cóż mogę panu o nim powiedzieć? -- rzekła, bawiąc się łańcuszkiem od zegarka.
Sentences_to: "What can I tell you about him?" she asked, and her fingers played nervously over the stops of her typewriter.
Translated_sentences: -- What can I tell you about him? -- she said, playing with her watch chain.

Sentences_from: Na prośby sir Henryka, doktor zaprowadził nas wszystkich do Alei Wiązów, aby nam pokazać, jak się rzeczy miały owej nocy.
Sentences_to: He has been excavating a barrow at Long Down, and has got a prehistoric skull which fills him with great joy. Never was there such a single-minded enthusiast as he!
Translated_sentences: At Sir Henry's request, the doctor took us all to the avenue of elms to show us how things had turned out that night.

Sentences_from: Cartwright”. -- A więc obie moje nici zerwane -- rzekł Holmes. -- Nic mnie tak nie podnieca, jak niepowodzenie.
Sentences_to: "There go two of my threads, Watson. There is nothing more stimulating than a case where everything goes against you.
Translated_sentences: Cartwright." -"So both my threads are broken," said Holmes. - Nothing excites me more than failure.

Sentences_from: -- Jego celem jest... morderstwo -- chłodne, wyrafinowane -- odparł. -- Nie pytaj mnie o szczegóły.
Sentences_to: "It is murder, Watson--refined, cold-blooded, deliberate murder. Do not ask me for particulars.
Translated_sentences: -- His goal is... murder -- cool, sophisticated, " he said. -- Don't ask me for details.

Sentences_from: Dziękuję. A chciałbym też zmienić pięciofuntowy banknot.
Sentences_to: And I should be glad to have change of this five-pound note."
Translated_sentences: Thank you. And I'd also like to change the five-pound note.

Sentences_from: Gdybyśmy go oszczędzili, mogliby to przypłacić życiem sąsiedzi, Stapletonowie naprzykład.
Sentences_to: With his brutal and violent nature, others would have to pay the price if we held our hands.
Translated_sentences: If we spared him, the neighbors, the Stapletons, for example, could pay for it with their lives.

Sentences_from: -- Tak, panie -- mówiła jakby w odpowiedzi na nasze myśli. -- Moje panieńskie nazwisko było Seldon, a to mój brat młodszy... Psuliśmy go za jego lat dziecinnych, wszystko mu było wolno, więc nabrał przekonania, że świat istnieje dla jego przyjemności...
Sentences_to: "Yes, sir, my name was Selden, and he is my younger brother. We humoured him too much when he was a lad, and gave him his own way in everything until he came to think that the world was made for his pleasure, and that he could do what he liked in it.
Translated_sentences: -- Yes, sir -- she spoke as if in answer to our thoughts. -- My maiden name was Seldon, and this is my younger brother... We spoiled him in his infancy, he was allowed to do everything, so he became convinced that the world exists for his pleasure...

Sentences_from: -- To prawda -- przytwierdził Barrymore. -- Mówiłem, że tajemnica nie moja i że nie mam prawa jej zdradzić.
Sentences_to: "That's the truth, sir," said Barrymore. "I said that it was not my secret and that I could not tell it to you.
Translated_sentences: -- It's true, " Barrymore said. -- I told you the secret wasn't mine and I had no right to tell her.

Sentences_from: Niedowiarstwo mogło jedynie skłonić Franklanda do udzielenia mi bliższych informacyj.
Sentences_to: "I should say that it was much more likely that it was the son of one of the moorland shepherds taking out his father's dinner."
Translated_sentences: The only thing that could have motivated Frankland to give me more information was disbelief.

Sentences_from: Holmes wyjął z koperty papier dużego formatu, rozłożył go na stole.
Sentences_to: Out of the envelope he took a half-sheet of foolscap paper folded into four.
Translated_sentences: Holmes took out a large sheet of paper from the envelope, spread it out on the table.

Sentences_from: -- Ponieważ Roger Baskerville, młodszy brat sir Karola, zmarł bezżennie i bezpotomnie, zatem majątek przeszedłby na dalekich krewnych, Desmondów.
Sentences_to: "Since Rodger Baskerville, Sir Charles's younger brother died unmarried, the estate would descend to the Desmonds, who are distant cousins.
Translated_sentences: -- Because Roger Baskerville, Sir Charles ' younger brother, died unmarried and without issue, so the estate would pass to distant relatives, the Desmonds.

Sentences_from: Niecierpliwiło mnie to często, ale nigdy do tego stopnia, jak owego wieczora. Czekało nas zadanie trudne i niebezpieczne, mieliśmy działać wspólnie, a jednak Holmes nie wyznaczał nam roli.
Sentences_to: Our conversation was hampered by the presence of the driver of the hired wagonette, so that we were forced to talk of trivial matters when our nerves were tense with emotion and anticipation.
Translated_sentences: I got impatient often, but never to the extent I did that night. We had a difficult and dangerous task ahead of us, we were supposed to work together, and yet Holmes did not assign us a role.

Sentences_from: W połowie drogi jest furtka, prowadząca na łąkę, za którą leży trzęsawisko.
Sentences_to: At the far end is an old tumble-down summer-house. Half-way down is the moor-gate, where the old gentleman left his cigar-ash.
Translated_sentences: In the middle of the road there is a gate leading to a meadow, behind which lies a quagmire.

Sentences_from: Były to jedyne oznaki życia; dokoła pustka i cisza, nigdzie nie mogłem dojrzeć śladów owej postaci widmowej, którą dostrzegłem parę dni temu.
Sentences_to: They were the only signs of human life which I could see, save only those prehistoric huts which lay thickly upon the slopes of the hills. Nowhere was there any trace of that lonely man whom I had seen on the same spot two nights before.
Translated_sentences: They were the only signs of life; around the emptiness and silence, nowhere could I see traces of this spectral figure, which I saw a few days ago.

Sentences_from: Powiedział odrazu, że jest detektywem i ofiarował mi dwie gwinee, jeżeli przez cały dzień będę spełniał jego rozkazy i o nic pytać nie będę.
Sentences_to: He said that he was a detective, and he offered me two guineas if I would do exactly what he wanted all day and ask no questions.
Translated_sentences: He said he was a detective and offered me two Guineas if I followed his orders all day and asked no questions.

Sentences_from: Doktor Mortimer pytał o powód moich indagacyj; zaspokoiłem jego ciekawość, nie mówiąc mu prawdy: po co tyle osób ma wiedzieć o tym liście?
Sentences_to: He wanted to know the object of my inquiries, but I managed to satisfy his curiosity without telling him too much, for there is no reason why we should take anyone into our confidence.
Translated_sentences: Dr. Mortimer asked the reason for my suggestions; I satisfied his curiosity by not telling him the truth: why should so many people know about this letter?

Sentences_from: Nie, on poprostu biegł, _uciekał_, aż wreszcie padł twarzą na ziemię.
Sentences_to: Why should a man walk on tiptoe down the alley?"
Translated_sentences: No, he just ran and ran and ran until he finally fell face down on the ground.

Sentences_from: -- A teraz opowiedz mi twoją wizytę u mrs.
Sentences_to: "That's better," said he, seeing the shadow rise from my face.
Translated_sentences: -- Now tell me about your visit to Mrs.

Sentences_from: Obaj wyciągnęliśmy ręce zziębnięte, a rozgrzawszy się, wodziliśmy oczyma po ścianach, zawieszonych zbrojami, strzelbami i myśliwskimi trofeami.
Sentences_to: Then we gazed round us at the high, thin window of old stained glass, the oak panelling, the stags' heads, the coats-of-arms upon the walls, all dim and sombre in the subdued light of the central lamp.
Translated_sentences: We both stretched out our cold hands, and warming ourselves, we ran our eyes along the walls, hung with armor, rifles and hunting trophies.

Sentences_from: Doktor Mortimer jest człowiekiem uczonym w swoim zakresie, biedny sir Karol był miłym towarzyszem.
Sentences_to: Dr. Mortimer is a most learned man in his own line. Poor Sir Charles was also an admirable companion.
Translated_sentences: Dr. Mortimer is a man of learning in his field, poor Sir Charles was a pleasant companion.

Sentences_from: Tok moich myśli został przerwany odgłosem kroków.
Sentences_to: You may possibly have heard my name from our mutual friend, Mortimer.
Translated_sentences: The flow of my thoughts was interrupted by the sound of footsteps.

Sentences_from: Czyż podobna, aby osoba tak przyzwoita i poważna miała w swoich żyłach tę samą krew, co słynny zbrodniarz?...
Sentences_to: Was it possible that this stolidly respectable person was of the same blood as one of the most notorious criminals in the country?
Translated_sentences: Is it akin to a person so decent and serious to have in his veins the same blood as a famous criminal?...

Sentences_from: -- I pomyśleć, że słyszeliśmy jego jęki i nie mogliśmy nadbiedz mu z pomocą....
Sentences_to: "That we should have heard his screams--my God, those screams!--and yet have been unable to save him!
Translated_sentences: -- And to think we heard him moaning and couldn't come to his aid....

Sentences_from: Korytarz przecięty jest balkonem, znajdującym się nad główną sienią i portykiem, ale biegnie dalej po jego drugiej stronie.
Sentences_to: I have told you that the corridor is broken by the balcony which runs round the hall, but that it is resumed upon the farther side.
Translated_sentences: The corridor is intersected by a balcony, located above the main hall and portico, but runs further on its other side.

Sentences_from: To światło jest sygnałem, że przygotowaliśmy dla niego pożywienie... a tamto światełko wskazuje, gdzie mamy je przynieść...
Sentences_to: The light is a signal to him that food is ready for him, and his light out yonder is to show the spot to which to bring it."
Translated_sentences: This light is a signal that we have prepared food for him... and that light over there tells us where to bring them...

Sentences_from: Ale dziewczyna, będąc skromną, i bogobojną, obawiała się go, jak szatana.
Sentences_to: It chanced that this Hugo came to love (if, indeed, so dark a passion may be known under so bright a name) the daughter of a yeoman who held lands near the Baskerville estate.
Translated_sentences: But the girl, being modest and God-fearing, feared him like Satan.

Sentences_from: A zatem do tego miejsca doszedł bezpiecznie.
Sentences_to: We know at least that he came so far in safety."
Translated_sentences: So he came to this place safely.

Sentences_from: Na ciele nie było żadnych obrażeń.
Sentences_to: There was certainly no physical injury of any kind.
Translated_sentences: There were no injuries on the body.

Sentences_from: To rzęrzenie było jego ostatnim oddechem.
Sentences_to: Holmes laid his hand upon him, and held it up again, with an exclamation of horror.
Translated_sentences: That rumbling was his last breath.

Sentences_from: -- Istotnie, Watson, przechodzisz sam siebie -- rzekł Holmes, zapalając papierosa. -- Muszę przyznać, że pańskie wnioski są słuszne.
Sentences_to: "Really, Watson, you excel yourself," said Holmes, pushing back his chair and lighting a cigarette. "I am bound to say that in all the accounts which you have been so good as to give of my own small achievements you have habitually underrated your own abilities.
Translated_sentences: -"Indeed, Watson, you are passing yourself," said Holmes, lighting a cigarette. -- I have to admit, your conclusions are correct.

Sentences_from: -- Twoja rozmowa z tą damę rzuciła właśnie światło na ten punkt ciemny.
Sentences_to: "That is one of the points upon which your own researches have shed a light. Your interview with the lady has cleared the situation very much.
Translated_sentences: -- Your conversation with that lady just shed light on that dark spot.

Sentences_from: Baskerville przyglądał mu się ze wzruszeniem, jako pobojowisku, na którem rozegrywały się tragiczne losy jego rodziny.
Sentences_to: There he sat, with his tweed suit and his American accent, in the corner of a prosaic railway-carriage, and yet as I looked at his dark and expressive face I felt more than ever how true a descendant he was of that long line of high-blooded, fiery, and masterful men. There were pride, valour, and strength in his thick brows, his sensitive nostrils, and his large hazel eyes.
Translated_sentences: Baskerville looked upon it with emotion, as a battlefield on which the tragic fate of his family played out.

Sentences_from: Oprócz p. Frankland w Lafterhall i naturalisty, p. Stapleton, w pobliżu niema ludzi inteligentnych.
Sentences_to: With the exception of Mr. Frankland, of Lafter Hall, and Mr. Stapleton, the naturalist, there are no other men of education within many miles.
Translated_sentences: Apart from p. Frankland in lafterhall and naturalist, P. Stapleton, there are no intelligent people around.

Sentences_from: Zaopatrzyliśmy go we wszystko, czego potrzebował, a następnie, przy sutej wieczerzy, opowiedzieliśmy baronetowi naszą przygodę, z opuszczeniem pewnych szczegółów.
Sentences_to: Between us we soon supplied his wants, and then over a belated supper we explained to the baronet as much of our experience as it seemed desirable that he should know.
Translated_sentences: We supplied him with everything he needed, and then, at supper, we told the baronet our adventure, leaving out certain details.

Sentences_from: -- Mam nadzieję, że go schwytam i nałożę mu kaganiec, ale potrzebuję pańskiej pomocy.
Sentences_to: "I think I will muzzle him and chain him all right if you will give me your help."
Translated_sentences: -- I hope to capture him and muzzle him, but I need your help.

Sentences_from: -- Zdaje mi się, że ztamtąd -- odparłem, wskazując na lewo.
Sentences_to: "There, I think." I pointed into the darkness.
Translated_sentences: -- I think it's from there -- I said, pointing to my left.

Sentences_from: -- Doprawdy, panie Holmes, to przechodzi wszelkie pojęcie! -- rzekł doktor Mortimer, patrząc na mego przyjaciela ze zdumieniem. -- Nie dość, że pan poznałeś odrazu, iż słowa zostały wycięte z dziennika, ale domyśliłeś się, z którego.
Sentences_to: "Really, Mr. Holmes, this exceeds anything which I could have imagined," said Dr. Mortimer, gazing at my friend in amazement. "I could understand anyone saying that the words were from a newspaper; but that you should name which, and add that it came from the leading article, is really one of the most remarkable things which I have ever known.
Translated_sentences: -- Indeed, Mr. Holmes, it passes any notion! -- said Dr. Mortimer, looking at my friend with astonishment. -- Not only did you immediately know that the words were cut from the diary, but you guessed from which.

Sentences_from: Przedewszystkiem postarał się osiąść jaknajbliżej siedziby swych przodków, powtóre -- nawiązać przyjazny stosunek z sir Karolem Baskerville, oraz z jego sąsiadami.
Sentences_to: "The baronet himself told him about the family hound, and so prepared the way for his own death. Stapleton, as I will continue to call him, knew that the old man's heart was weak and that a shock would kill him.
Translated_sentences: In the first place he endeavoured to settle as near as possible to the seat of his ancestors, and, again, to establish friendly relations with Sir Charles Baskerville, and with his neighbours.

Sentences_from: Stapleton poznał ją przypadkowo, zainteresował się niby jej losem i wzbudził dla niej współczucie w litościwem sercu baroneta; że zaś potrafił zyskiwać względy kobiet i przedstawił się jako kawaler, wkrótce zdobył nietylko zaufanie, lecz i serce pięknej Laury; dawał jej też do zrozumienia, że się z nią ożeni, jeśli ona rozwiedzie się z mężem.
Sentences_to: He therefore put pressure upon Mrs. Lyons to write this letter, imploring the old man to give her an interview on the evening before his departure for London. He then, by a specious argument, prevented her from going, and so had the chance for which he had waited.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton met her by Chance, took an interest in her fate, and inspired her with compassion in the benevolent heart of the baronet; and, as he was able to win the affections of women, and presented himself as a bachelor, he soon won not only the confidence, but also the heart of the beautiful Laura; and intimated to her that he would marry her if she divorced her husband.

Sentences_from: Przypomniała mi się dziwna przestroga, wycięta ze wstępnego artykułu _Timesa_.
Sentences_to: Suddenly my thoughts were interrupted by the sound of running feet behind me and by a voice which called me by name.
Translated_sentences: I was reminded of a strange warning, cut from the initial article _timesa_.

Sentences_from: Trzymamy go. Watson! gotów jestem założyć się, że jutro wpadnie w moje sieci, tak, jak motyle, za którymi sam się ugania.
Sentences_to: We have him, Watson, we have him, and I dare swear that before to-morrow night he will be fluttering in our net as helpless as one of his own butterflies. A pin, a cork, and a card, and we add him to the Baker Street collection!"
Translated_sentences: We got him. Watson! I'm willing to bet he'll fall into my net tomorrow, just like the butterflies he's chasing.

Sentences_from: Nic dziwnego, że mój stryj stał się dziwakiem. Połóżmy się wcześniej.
Sentences_to: I don't wonder that my uncle got a little jumpy if he lived all alone in such a house as this.
Translated_sentences: No wonder my uncle became a freak. Let's go to bed early.

Sentences_from: Nie jestem tchórzem, Watson, lecz to szczekanie ścięło mi krew w żyłach.
Sentences_to: I don't think that I am a coward, Watson, but that sound seemed to freeze my very blood.
Translated_sentences: I'm not a coward, Watson, but that barking cut my blood.

Sentences_from: _17 października._ Przez cały dzień deszcz padał.
Sentences_to: OCTOBER 17TH.--All day to-day the rain poured down, rustling on the ivy and dripping from the eaves.
Translated_sentences: _17 October._ It rained all day.

Sentences_from: To są fakty realne, lecz owym nieznajomym może być zarówno przyjaciel, jak i wróg.
Sentences_to: A stranger then is still dogging us, just as a stranger dogged us in London.
Translated_sentences: These are real facts, but this stranger can be both friend and foe.

Sentences_from: Kilka osób z sąsiedztwa postarało się dostarczyć jej uczciwego zarobku.
Sentences_to: Her story got about, and several of the people here did something to enable her to earn an honest living.
Translated_sentences: Several people in the neighborhood tried to provide her with a fair wage.

Sentences_from: Spacerowałem właśnie z moim przyjacielem, gdy doleciał nas krzyk przeraźliwy.
Sentences_to: My friend and I were strolling on the moor when we heard a cry."
Translated_sentences: I was walking with my friend when we heard a terrible scream.

Sentences_from: Wahałem się między poczuciem delikatności a obowiązku.
Sentences_to: Still, I could see no better course than to observe him from the hill, and to clear my conscience by confessing to him afterwards what I had done. It is true that if any sudden danger had threatened him I was too far away to be of use, and yet I am sure that you will agree with me that the position was very difficult, and that there was nothing more which I could do.
Translated_sentences: I hesitated between a sense of delicacy and duty.

Sentences_from: Widziałem, jak wszedł do pokoju, w którym pozostawił był sir Henryka.
Sentences_to: I saw him rejoin his guest, and I crept quietly back to where my companions were waiting to tell them what I had seen.
Translated_sentences: I saw him enter the room in which he had left Sir Henry.

Sentences_from: -- Zechciej więc pan uwiadomić mnie teraz o tem, czego nikt nie wie.
Sentences_to: "Then let me have the private ones."
Translated_sentences: -- So you want to let me know now what no one knows.

Sentences_from: Ubierzemy się zaraz i przed widowiskiem pojedziemy na obiad do pierwszorzędnej restauracyi. Dobrze?...
Sentences_to: Might I trouble you then to be ready in half an hour, and we can stop at Marcini's for a little dinner on the way?"
Translated_sentences: We'll get dressed right away, and before the show, we'll go to dinner at a first-rate restaurant. Okay?...

Sentences_from: -- Jeszcze jedno pytanie -- rzekłem, wstając. -- Wszak między nami nie powinno być sekretów.
Sentences_to: "One last question, Holmes," I said, as I rose. "Surely there is no need of secrecy between you and me.
Translated_sentences: -- One more question -- I said, standing up. -- After all, there should be no secrets between us.

Sentences_from: Mrs. Lyons nie miała wprawdzie pojęcia ani o jednem, ani o drugiem, lecz zastanowiło ją, że śmierć starego gentlemana wynikła o godzinie, wyznaczonej na spotkanie z nią.
Sentences_to: Mrs. Stapleton knew that he had designs upon the old man, and also of the existence of the hound.
Translated_sentences: Mrs. Lyons had no idea of either, but it occurred to her that the old gentleman's death had occurred at the hour appointed to meet her.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli pani nie może przytoczyć mi ważniejszego powodu, to tym argumentem nie zdołam go skłonić do opuszczenia Baskerville-Hall.
Sentences_to: I fear that unless you can give me some more definite information than this it would be impossible to get him to move."
Translated_sentences: If you cannot give me a more important reason, I shall not be able to persuade him to leave Baskerville Hall by this argument.

Sentences_from: Patrząc na Sherlocka, spostrzegłem, że tłumi wewnętrzne wzburzenie.
Sentences_to: I could see as he looked down that he was repressing some internal emotion.
Translated_sentences: When I looked at Sherlock, I saw that he was suppressing an inner turmoil.

Sentences_from: W całej okolicy zapanował strach przesądny. Nikt po nocy nie przejdzie przez łąkę.
Sentences_to: I assure you that there is a reign of terror in the district, and that it is a hardy man who will cross the moor at night."
Translated_sentences: Superstitious fear prevailed throughout the area. No one will cross the meadow after dark.

Sentences_from: Nikczemnik poznał odrazu, jaką może stąd korzyść osiągnąć; obmyślił dla baroneta śmierć niezawodną, za którą nikt nie mógł być pociągnięty do odpowiedzialności.
Sentences_to: "Having conceived the idea he proceeded to carry it out with considerable finesse. An ordinary schemer would have been content to work with a savage hound.
Translated_sentences: The wretch knew at once what advantage he could gain from this; he devised for the baronet a certain death, for which no one could be held responsible.

Sentences_from: A jednak sam fakt może się wydać błahym.
Sentences_to: And yet it may seem a small matter in itself.
Translated_sentences: And yet the fact itself may seem trivial.

Sentences_from: W razie napaści, któż przyjdzie z pomocą?...
Sentences_to: Look at Mr. Stapleton's house, for example, with no one but himself to defend it.
Translated_sentences: In the event of an assault, who will come to the rescue?...

Sentences_from: Przed samym obiadem wręczono mu dwie depesze: Pierwsza brzmiała w te słowa:
Sentences_to: Just before dinner two telegrams were handed in. The first ran:--
Translated_sentences: Before dinner, he was handed two dispatches: the first was in these words:

Sentences_from: Powiedz mi, jaki on ma w tem cel?
Sentences_to: What is the meaning of it all? What is he after?"
Translated_sentences: Tell me, what's his purpose?

Sentences_from: -- I owszem, Watson zna mój system.
Sentences_to: "On the contrary, I think we are particularly hot upon the trail, Sir Henry.
Translated_sentences: -- And yes, Watson knows my system.

Sentences_from: Ale wpierw czekał mnie przykry obowiązek uwiadomienia Barrymorów o śmierci Seldona.
Sentences_to: But first I had the unpleasant duty of breaking the news to Barrymore and his wife.

Sentences_from: -- Sir Karol uchodził za bogacza, ale i my nie mieliśmy pojęcia, że jest tak dalece bogatym.
Sentences_to: "Sir Charles had the reputation of being rich, but we did not know how very rich he was until we came to examine his securities.
Translated_sentences: - Sir Charles thought he was rich, but we had no idea he was so rich.

Sentences_from: A teraz, doniosłszy ci o zbiegłym więźniu, opisawszy ci rodzeństwo Stapleton, doktora Mortimer i pana Frankland z Lafter-Hall, powiem ci coś bardzo ciekawego o Barrymorze i o niezwykłych zdarzeniach zeszłej nocy.
Sentences_to: And now, having brought you up to date in the escaped convict, the Stapletons, Dr. Mortimer, and Frankland, of Lafter Hall, let me end on that which is most important and tell you more about the Barrymores, and especially about the surprising development of last night.
Translated_sentences: And now that I've told you about the escaped prisoner, and described the Stapleton siblings, Dr. Mortimer and Mr. Frankland of lafter hall, I'm going to tell you something very interesting about Barrymore and the extraordinary events of last night.

Sentences_from: Wtem doleciał mnie znowu odgłos kroków.

Sentences_from: Znaleźliśmy się w ogromnej, sklepionej sieni, z wiązaniami z belek dębowych.
Sentences_to: In the great old-fashioned fireplace behind the high iron dogs a log-fire crackled and snapped.

Sentences_from: -- Pani krzywdzisz pamięć sir Karola -- rzekłem. -- On ten list spalił, ale można odczytać list nawet po spaleniu...

Sentences_from: Słońce padało na jej twarz chłodną, płaską i brzydką. Duże, wyraziste oczy były zaczerwienione; spojrzała na mnie z pod zapuchłych powiek.
Sentences_to: The other is my wife, and I can answer for it that the sound could not have come from her."

Sentences_from: Ale nie możesz pan jechać sam.

Sentences_from: Ale ten nieznośny brat nie pozwala nam się porozumieć.

Translated_sentences: But this obnoxious brother won't let us communicate.

Sentences_from: Przybyłem do pana, panie Holmes, bo uznaję własną niepraktyczność, a jestem postawiony wobec bardzo trudnego zagadnienia.
Sentences_to: I came to you, Mr. Holmes, because I recognized that I am myself an unpractical man and because I am suddenly confronted with a most serious and extraordinary problem.
Translated_sentences: I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, because I recognize my own impracticality, and I am faced with a very difficult question.

Sentences_from: Już w pół-śnie usłyszałem zgrzyt klucza we drzwiach, ale nie mogłem umiarkować, w których.
Sentences_to: Instantly I made my way back to my room, and very shortly came the stealthy steps passing once more upon their return journey.
Translated_sentences: Already in a half-dream I heard the rattle of a key in the door, but I could not moderate in which.

Sentences_from: W ciągu trzech lat ostatnich okradziono w Devonshire cztery dwory.
Sentences_to: It is suggestive that during the last three years there have been four considerable burglaries in the West Country, for none of which was any criminal ever arrested.

Sentences_from: -- Miałem szkołę w jednem z hrabstw północnych -- mówił Stapleton -- ale ten rodzaj pracy nie odpowiadał mojemu temperamentowi, chociaż obcowanie z dziećmi, urabianie ich umysłów, miało dla mnie dużo uroku.
Sentences_to: "It was in the north country. The work to a man of my temperament was mechanical and uninteresting, but the privilege of living with youth, of helping to mould those young minds, and of impressing them with one's own character and ideals, was very dear to me.
Translated_sentences: -"I had a school in one of the northern counties," Stapleton said, " but this kind of work did not suit my temperament, although it did have a lot of charm for me to commune with children, to work on their minds.

Sentences_from: Odgłos wystrzału zwiastował Stapletonowi, że zasadzka chybiona.
Sentences_to: He fled when he knew the game was up, still clutching it.

Sentences_from: Byłoby to dla mnie spokojem, szczęściem, wszystkiem na świecie.
Sentences_to: It meant everything to me--peace of mind, happiness, self-respect--everything.

Sentences_from: -- Najlepiej złożyć go w jednej z jaskiń, dopóki nie uwiadomimy policyi.

Translated_sentences: -- Best to deposit it in one of the caves until we notify policya.

Sentences_from: Może to pan nazwać domysłem, ale ja jestem pewien, że adres został skreślony w hotelu.
Sentences_to: It is the scientific use of the imagination, but we have always some material basis on which to start our speculation. Now, you would call it a guess, no doubt, but I am almost certain that this address has been written in a hotel."
Translated_sentences: Call it a guess, but I'm pretty sure the address was crossed out at the hotel.

Sentences_from: Sherlock Holmes odwiózł mnie na dworzec i udzielił ostatnich rad i wskazówek.
Sentences_to: Mr. Sherlock Holmes drove with me to the station and gave me his last parting injunctions and advice.
Translated_sentences: Sherlock Holmes drove me to the station and gave me his last words of advice and guidance.

Sentences_from: Mój przyjaciel umilkł, ale nie odrywał oczu od portretu. Dopiero po naszem rozejściu się na spoczynek dowiedziałem się, dlaczego to płótno budzi w nim tak żywo zaciekawienie.
Sentences_to: Holmes said little more, but the picture of the old roysterer seemed to have a fascination for him, and his eyes were continually fixed upon it during supper. It was not until later, when Sir Henry had gone to his room, that I was able to follow the trend of his thoughts.
Translated_sentences: My friend fell silent, but he did not take his eyes off the portrait. It was only after we retired that I learned why this canvas is so vividly interesting to him.

Sentences_from: Smutne to zresztą konkury. Gdzieżeś się ukrywał?
Sentences_to: Where had you engaged a seat?"

Sentences_from: -- Więc w jaki sposób mogę panu dopomódz?
Sentences_to: "Then, how can I assist you?"

Sentences_from: A jednak, mówiąc to, kłamał. Po śniadaniu, spotkałem mrs.

Sentences_from: Lada chwila mógł cofnąć się i zniknąć wśród ciemności.
Sentences_to: Any instant he might dash out the light and vanish in the darkness.
Translated_sentences: Any minute now, he could have stepped back and disappeared into the darkness.

Sentences_from: Jest to człowiek niemłody, siwy, temperamentu cholerycznego, zawołany pieniacz; pół majątku stracił na procesy. Nie chodzi mu o przedmiot sporny, lecz o sam proces.
Sentences_to: His passion is for the British law, and he has spent a large fortune in litigation. He fights for the mere pleasure of fighting and is equally ready to take up either side of a question, so that it is no wonder that he has found it a costly amusement.
Translated_sentences: He is a man of no age, of grey hair, of choleric temperament, called a foaler; he has lost half his fortune to lawsuits. He is not referring to the subject matter at issue, but to the process itself.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne to trzęsawisko -- mówił, wskazując mi olbrzymią płaszczyznę, pokrytą piaskami i trawą -- dla nieoswojonego oka wydaje się monotonnem i smutnem, ale kto się przyzwyczai do tych fal piaszczystych; dla tego mają one urok nieprzeparty, a zawierają tyle tajemnic!...
Sentences_to: "It is a wonderful place, the moor," said he, looking round over the undulating downs, long green rollers, with crests of jagged granite foaming up into fantastic surges. "You never tire of the moor. You cannot think the wonderful secrets which it contains. It is so vast, and so barren, and so mysterious."
Translated_sentences: -"It is a strange quagmire," he said, pointing out to me a huge plane covered with sand and grass, " to the untrained eye it seems monotonous and sad, but who gets used to these waves of sand; for that they have an irresistible charm, and contain so many secrets!...

Sentences_from: O czternaście mil dalej -- więzienie państwowe Princetown.
Sentences_to: Here are two moorland farm-houses, High Tor and Foulmire.
Translated_sentences: Fourteen miles away -- Princeton state prison.

Sentences_from: Szedłem śladami, pozostawionemi w Alei Wiązów, obejrzałem miejsce przy furtce, gdzie sir Karol zatrzymał się, i zmiarkowałem, że od owego miejsca szedł na palcach i że nie było śladu innych kroków, oprócz późniejszych, Barrymora.
Sentences_to: I followed the footsteps down the Yew Alley, I saw the spot at the moor-gate where he seemed to have waited, I remarked the change in the shape of the prints after that point, I noted that there were no other footsteps save those of Barrymore on the soft gravel, and finally I carefully examined the body, which had not been touched until my arrival.
Translated_sentences: I followed the footprints left in the avenue of elms, looked at the place by the gate where Sir Charles had stopped, and measured that from that place he had walked on his toes, and that there was no sign of any other steps than those of Barrymore.

Sentences_from: Chciałam prosić sir Karola o pomoc.
Sentences_to: I have no reason to be ashamed of it.
Translated_sentences: I wanted to ask Sir Charles for help.

Sentences_from: Ale Barrymore w toku śledztwa uczynił jedno zeznanie fałszywe.
Sentences_to: But one false statement was made by Barrymore at the inquest.

Sentences_from: Zanim jednak zdążyła mi odpowiedzieć, ten jej utrapiony brat wpadł między nas, jak kula.
Sentences_to: If he had not been her brother I should have known better how to answer him. As it was I told him that my feelings towards his sister were such as I was not ashamed of, and that I hoped that she might honour me by becoming my wife.

Sentences_from: Nie, mój drogi, musimy pogodzić się z myślą, że trzeba czekać i działać z ukrycia.

Sentences_from: -- A ów jeździec, naprzeciwko mnie, w aksamitnym spencerze?

Sentences_from: Miałbym pańskie życie na sumieniu! -- zawołał. -- Pan nie wróciłbyś z tej wycieczki.
Sentences_to: "Your blood would be upon my head. I assure you that there would not be the least chance of your coming back alive.

Sentences_from: -- Aby pani oszczędzić publicznego skandalu.

Sentences_to: Just under the head was a broad silver band nearly an inch across. "To James Mortimer, M.R.C.S., from his friends of the C.C.H.," was engraved upon it, with the date "1884."

Sentences_from: Powinszuj mi, Holmes, i przyznaj, że nie zawiodłem twego zaufania. Ta zagadka została wyjaśniona w jedną noc.
Sentences_to: I have said "by one night's work," but, in truth, it was by two nights' work, for on the first we drew entirely blank.

Sentences_from: -- Nie robiłem nic złego -- szepnął. -- Trzymałem świecę w oknie.

Sentences_from: „Przywieźli biedaczkę na zamek i osadzili ją w komnacie wieżowej, Hugon i jego towarzysze zasiedli do nocnej uczty, wedle zwyczaju.
Sentences_to: When they had brought her to the Hall the maiden was placed in an upper chamber, while Hugo and his friends sat down to a long carouse, as was their nightly custom.

Sentences_from: Wyobrażałem go sobie tęższym i groźniejszym.

Sentences_from: Naprzód pojechaliśmy pod hotel Northumberland i czekaliśmy tam, aż dwóch gentlemanów wyszło. Wsiedli do dorożki.
Sentences_to: First we drove down to the Northumberland Hotel and waited there until two gentlemen came out and took a cab from the rank.

Sentences_from: Ale wiadomo, czem są pióra i kałamarze hotelowe.

Sentences_from: Co ma być, niech się stanie.

Sentences_from: Niepodobna było jej opuścić i dać jej się zmarnować zupełnie.

Sentences_from: -- Gotów jestem przypuszczać, że tak jest.

Sentences_from: Pochylił się nad nią, chciał ją pocałować -- zasłoniła się ręką.

Sentences_from: Mógł był wprawdzie trzymać go w oficynie Merripit-House, ale byłoby to ryzykownem.

Sentences_from: Stąpaliśmy powoli wśród ciemności. Światełko płonęło wciąż w jednym punkcie.
Sentences_to: We stumbled slowly along in the darkness, with the black loom of the craggy hills around us, and the yellow speck of light burning steadily in front.
Translated_sentences: We walked slowly through the darkness. The light was still on at one point.

Sentences_from: Wątpię, czy Stapleton posunie tak dalece egoizm, aby się sprzeciwić temu świetnemu małżeństwu, choć widocznie nie życzy sobie zażyłości pomiędzy siostrą a baronetem; parę razy przeszkadzał im w rozmowie sam na sam.
Sentences_to: He is much attached to her, no doubt, and would lead a lonely life without her, but it would seem the height of selfishness if he were to stand in the way of her making so brilliant a marriage.
Translated_sentences: I doubt if Stapleton will go so far as to oppose this EXCELLENT marriage, though he evidently does not wish intimacy between his sister and the baronet; he has interrupted their private conversation on several occasions.

Sentences_from: Kilkakrotnie Stapleton czyhał na niego z psem, lecz bezskutecznie.
Sentences_to: Several times Stapleton lurked about with his hound, but without avail.
