Sentences_from: -- To tak zwane Grimpen-Mire,[1] błota nieprzebyte.
Sentences_to: "That is the great Grimpen Mire," said he.
Translated_sentences: -- This is the so-called Grimpen-Mire, [1] mud unspoiled.

Sentences_from: Wyprowadzam stąd wniosek, że autorem anonimu jest człowiek wykształcony, który chce uchodzić za nieuka; sam fakt, że ukrywa swe pismo, dowodzi, że pan znasz, lub że mógłbyś poznać to pismo. Dalej: słowa nie są naklejone w prostej linii; i tak, naprzykład, _życie_ nie jest na swojem miejscu właściwem.
Sentences_to: Have you read anything else in this message, Mr. Holmes?"
Translated_sentences: I infer from this that the author of the anonymous letter is an educated man who wishes to pretend to be a non-scholar; the very fact that he conceals his handwriting proves that you know, or could have known, the handwriting. Further: words are not pasted in a straight line; and so, for example, life is not in its proper place.

Sentences_from: Brzmiało w te słowa: _Jeżeli dbasz o życie, strzeż się trzęsawiska_ Tylko jedno słowo: „trzęsawiska” było wypisane drukowanemi literami, atramentem.[A]
Sentences_to: Across the middle of it a single sentence had been formed by the expedient of pasting printed words upon it. It ran: "As you value your life or your reason keep away from the moor."
Translated_sentences: It said: _if you care about life, beware of the quagmire_ only one word: "quagmire" was written in printed letters, in ink.[A]

Sentences_from: Gotów jest mi przyrzec jej rękę, jeżeli wzamian zobowiążę się słowem honoru, że przez trzy miesiące nie wspomnę jej o miłości, nie będę starał się widywać jej sam na sam i zadowolę się zwykłym stosunkiem towarzyskim.
Sentences_to: He would withdraw all opposition upon his part if I would promise for three months to let the matter rest and to be content with cultivating the lady's friendship during that time without claiming her love.
Translated_sentences: He is ready to promise me her hand, if in return I promise with my word of honor that for three months I will not mention her love, I will not try to see her alone, and I will be content with ordinary social intercourse.

Sentences_from: Jest członkiem szwedzkiego Towarzystwa patologicznego, autorem wielu artykułów, jako to: „Kilka przykładów atawizmu” (drukowany w „Lancet” w r. 1882), „Czy idziemy z biegiem postępu?”
Sentences_to: Corresponding member of the Swedish Pathological Society. Author of 'Some Freaks of Atavism' (Lancet 1882).
Translated_sentences: He is a member of the Swedish pathological society, the author of many articles, such as:" some examples of atavism "(printed in the" Lancet "in 1882)," do we go with the progress?”

Sentences_from: Co to wszystko znaczy -- nie wiem, lecz w każdym razie dzieją się w tym domu rzeczy dziwne, nie rokujące nic dobrego. Wcześniej, czy później, wyświetlimy zagadkę.
Sentences_to: Long afterwards when I had fallen into a light sleep I heard a key turn somewhere in a lock, but I could not tell whence the sound came. What it all means I cannot guess, but there is some secret business going on in this house of gloom which sooner or later we shall get to the bottom of.
Translated_sentences: What all this means -- I don't know, but in any case, strange things are happening in this house that don't bode well. Sooner or later, we'll figure out the puzzle.

Sentences_from: Odwiedzał nas często, mówił z przejęciem o klątwie, ciążącej nad jego rodem.
Sentences_to: We knew him very intimately, for his favourite walk was over the moor to our house.
Translated_sentences: He came to visit us often, spoke movingly of the curse hanging over his family.

Sentences_from: -- Ja mówię nie o _nim_, ale o sir Henryku.
Sentences_to: "No, no, I did not mean my husband. Sir Henry?
Translated_sentences: -- I'm not talking about him.I'm talking about Sir Henry.

Sentences_from: -- Pozwoli pan, że, nie zsiadając, odjadę do domu -- rzekł doktor Mortimer. -- Czeka na mnie żona.
Sentences_to: "You don't mind my driving straight home, Sir Henry?" said Dr. Mortimer. "My wife is expecting me."
Translated_sentences: -"Let me go home without sitting down," said Dr. Mortimer. -- My wife's waiting for me.

Sentences_from: Dama, uchodząca tutaj za miss Stapleton, jest wistocie jego żoną.
Sentences_to: The lady who has passed here as Miss Stapleton is in reality his wife."
Translated_sentences: The lady who married Miss Stapleton here is actually his wife.

Sentences_from: -- Bo laska, choć pierwotnie ładna, jest tak zniszczona, że żaden lekarz miejski nie chciałby jej używać.
Sentences_to: "Because this stick, though originally a very handsome one has been so knocked about that I can hardly imagine a town practitioner carrying it.
Translated_sentences: -- Because the cane, though originally pretty, is so damaged that no city doctor would want to use it.

Sentences_from: Ja coś wiem i powinienem był powiedzieć to wcześniej, ale wykryłem to po skończonem śledztwie.
Sentences_to: I know something, Sir Henry, and perhaps I should have said it before, but it was long after the inquest that I found it out.
Translated_sentences: I know something, and I should have told you sooner, but I found out after the investigation was over.

Sentences_from: Taki jest teren, na którym rozegrała się owa tragedya.
Sentences_to: Between and around these scattered points extends the desolate, lifeless moor.
Translated_sentences: This is the area where this tragedy took place.

Sentences_from: Słyszeliśmy przed sobą warczenie psa i wołanie o pomoc sir Henryka.
Sentences_to: I am reckoned fleet of foot, but he outpaced me as much as I outpaced the little professional.
Translated_sentences: We heard the dog growling in front of us and Sir Henry calling for help.

Sentences_from: -- Czy Barrymore został wymieniony w testamencie sir Karola? -- pytał Holmes.
Sentences_to: "Did Barrymore profit at all by Sir Charles's will?" asked Holmes.
Translated_sentences: -- Was Barrymore mentioned in Sir Charles's will? - Holmes asked.

Sentences_from: Oboje z bratem zmartwiliśmy się bardzo śmiercią sir Karola.
Sentences_to: "My brother and I were very much shocked by the death of Sir Charles.
Translated_sentences: My brother and I were both very worried about the death of Sir Charles.

Sentences_from: -- Czy to było tutaj?... -- spytał półgłosem.
Sentences_to: "Was it here?" he asked in a low voice.
Translated_sentences: -- Was it here?... -- he asked in a low voice.

Sentences_from: Patrz, rzuciłeś niedopalony papieros, zapewne w chwili, gdyś zdecydował się wejść do tej jaskini.
Sentences_to: You threw it down, no doubt, at that supreme moment when you charged into the empty hut."
Translated_sentences: Look, you threw a half-smoked cigarette, probably the moment you decided to enter this cave.

Sentences_from: Osiedliliśmy się tutaj wkrótce po przybyciu sir Karola, ale moje upodobania przyrodnicze skłaniają mnie do ciągłych wędrówek, to też poznałem każdą niemal piędź ziemi. Sądzę, że nikt tutaj nie zna jej lepiej odemnie.
Sentences_to: We came shortly after Sir Charles settled. But my tastes led me to explore every part of the country round, and I should think that there are few men who know it better than I do."
Translated_sentences: We settled here soon after Sir Charles's arrival, but my natural predilections lead me to wander constantly, and I have come to know almost every inch of the earth. I don't think anyone here knows her better than me.

Sentences_from: Nawet zamach na sir Henryka, który skończył się śmiercią Seldona, nieszczęsnego więźnia, nie mógł nam pomódz do wykazania zbrodniczości Stapletona.
Sentences_to: "By the time that you discovered me upon the moor I had a complete knowledge of the whole business, but I had not a case which could go to a jury. Even Stapleton's attempt upon Sir Henry that night which ended in the death of the unfortunate convict did not help us much in proving murder against our man.
Translated_sentences: Even the assassination of Sir Henry, which ended in the death of Seldon, the unfortunate prisoner, could not help us to prove Stapleton's crime.

Sentences_from: Miałem ochotę odmówić ze względu na sir Henryka, ale przypomniałem sobie, że jest zajęty korespondencyą; nie mogłem mu dopomódz, a z drugiej strony, Holmes kazał mi poznawać sąsiedztwo. Więc przyjąłem zaproszenie pana Stapleton i weszliśmy razem na ścieżkę.
Sentences_to: My first thought was that I should be by Sir Henry's side. But then I remembered the pile of papers and bills with which his study table was littered. It was certain that I could not help with those. And Holmes had expressly said that I should study the neighbours upon the moor. I accepted Stapleton's invitation, and we turned together down the path.
Translated_sentences: I was tempted to refuse on account of Sir Henry, but I remembered that he was busy with correspondence; I could not help him, and, on the other hand, Holmes made me know the neighbourhood. So I accepted Mr. Stapleton's invitation and we walked down the path together.

Sentences_from: Jedną z wad Sherlocka Holmes -- jeśli można to nazwać wadą -- jest skrytość.
Sentences_to: One of Sherlock Holmes's defects--if, indeed, one may call it a defect--was that he was exceedingly loath to communicate his full plans to any other person until the instant of their fulfilment.
Translated_sentences: One of the drawbacks of Sherlock Holmes -- if you can call it a flaw -- is secrecy.

Sentences_from: Dowodzenie było bardzo logiczne. -- Bezwątpienia -- odparłem -- ale skąd pan wie, że on kryje się na bagnie?
Sentences_to: He certainly seemed to be getting uncomfortably near the truth. "No doubt," said I; "but how do you know that he is anywhere upon the moor?"
Translated_sentences: The command was very logical. -"No doubt," I said, " but how do you know he's hiding in the swamp?

Sentences_from: Żona domyślała się jego planów, lecz obawiała się ostrzedz upatrzoną ofiarę.
Sentences_to: If the letter should fall into Stapleton's hands her own life would not be safe.
Translated_sentences: The wife guessed his plans, but was afraid to warn the victim.

Sentences_from: Wzruszyłem ramionami. -- Jeżeli istotnie ma opuścić Anglię, uwolni to kraj od utrzymywania jednego więcej łotra -- odrzekłem.
Sentences_to: I shrugged my shoulders. "If he were safely out of the country it would relieve the tax-payer of a burden."
Translated_sentences: I shrugged. -"If he is indeed to leave England, it will free the country from keeping one more villain," I replied.

Sentences_from: Pozwoli mi pan, panie Holmes, zbadać swoją czaszkę.
Sentences_to: You interest me very much, Mr. Holmes.
Translated_sentences: Allow me, Mr. Holmes, to examine your skull.

Sentences_from: Nie mówiliśmy o tej sprawie, dopiero gdyśmy wrócili do apartamentu sir Henryka, oznajmił nam swoją decyzyę.
Sentences_to: It was in the private sitting-room to which we afterwards repaired that Holmes asked Baskerville what were his intentions.
Translated_sentences: We didn't talk about the matter until we got back to Sir Henry's suite, and he told us his decision.

Sentences_from: Holmes za pośrednictwem baroneta chciał przekonać Stapletonów, żeśmy wyjechali istotnie, a my tymczasem zjawimy się w chwili grożącego niebezpieczeństwa.
Sentences_to: He would use the baronet in order to convince the Stapletons that we were really gone, while we should actually return at the instant when we were likely to be needed.
Translated_sentences: Holmes, through the baronet, wanted to convince the Stapletons that we had indeed left, and that we would arrive at the moment of danger.

Sentences_from: Nie było w nich namiętności, lecz niezłomna, okrutna wola; tryskała ona z oczu stalowych, zdradzały ją usta wązkie, zaciśnięte.
Sentences_to: It was not a brutal countenance, but it was prim, hard, and stern, with a firm-set, thin-lipped mouth, and a coldly intolerant eye.
Translated_sentences: There was no passion in them, but an unflinching, cruel will; it gushed from the eyes of steel, betrayed her narrow, clenched lips.

Sentences_from: -- Przeklęta mgła! -- mruczał Holmes. -- Ogarnie nas niebawem, a wtedy wszystko stracone.
Sentences_to: The night was clear and fine above us. The stars shone cold and bright, while a half-moon bathed the whole scene in a soft, uncertain light.
Translated_sentences: -- Damn fog! - Holmes muttered. -- It will take us soon, and then all is lost.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne te bagna, prawda? -- rzekł jakby z dumą.
Sentences_to: "Queer place, the moor!" said he.
Translated_sentences: -- Strange swamp, isn't it? -- he said it with pride.

Sentences_from: Zapisani są w księgach zakładu fotograficznego jako „państwo Vandelour”, ale łatwo poznać i ją, i jego.
Sentences_to: It is indorsed 'Mr. and Mrs. Vandeleur,' but you will have no difficulty in recognizing him, and her also, if you know her by sight.
Translated_sentences: They are recorded in the books of the photographic establishment as "Mr. and Mrs. vandelour", but it is easy to recognize both her and him.

Sentences_from: Chciałbym się dowiedzieć o tem, co ukrywaliście przedemną.
Sentences_to: It is time that you kept your promise and gave me a full account of what we are all driving at."
Translated_sentences: I'd like to know what you've been hiding from me.

Sentences_from: -- Słuchaj, Barrymore -- rzekłem. -- Przybyłem tu w interesie twojego pana.
Sentences_to: "Now, listen to me, Barrymore! I have no interest in this matter but that of your master.
Translated_sentences: -- Look, Barrymore -- I said. -- I came here on behalf of your lord.

Sentences_from: -- A tamto, po drugiej stronie?
Sentences_to: "And the one beyond, which shines so brightly?"
Translated_sentences: -- What about that one on the other side?

Sentences_from: Trzymałem się gościńca, dopóki mógł mnie widzieć, następnie skręciłem w bok i dążyłem w stronę góry, po której przeszedł chłopak.
Sentences_to: I kept the road as long as his eye was on me, and then I struck off across the moor and made for the stony hill over which the boy had disappeared.
Translated_sentences: I held on to the man as long as he could see me, then I turned aside and headed for the mountain the boy had climbed.

Sentences_from: Sprawa nieczysta. Możemy się śmiać, ale ci powiem, że chciałbym cię już widzieć tutaj z powrotem.
Sentences_to: I can only wish you better luck in Devonshire. But I'm not easy in my mind about it."
Translated_sentences: Dirty business. We can laugh, but let me tell you, I'd like to see you back here.

Sentences_from: A więc śledzi nas jakiś nieznajomy -- zapewne ten sam, co w Londynie.
Sentences_to: His nerves have been strangely shaken by that sound upon the moor.
Translated_sentences: So we're being followed by a stranger -- probably the same one we saw in London.

Sentences_from: Od owego punktu, rząd wetkniętych w błoto gałęzi wskazywał kępki ziemi, po których można było przejść suchą nogą.
Sentences_to: It helped us to realize the horror of this woman's life when we saw the eagerness and joy with which she laid us on her husband's track. We left her standing upon the thin peninsula of firm, peaty soil which tapered out into the widespread bog.
Translated_sentences: From this point, a row of branches stuck in the mud indicated clumps of earth, along which it was possible to walk with a dry foot.

Sentences_from: Stanął przed detektywem w postawie pełnej uszanowania.
Sentences_to: He stood now gazing with great reverence at the famous detective.
Translated_sentences: He stood before the detective in a respectful attitude.

Sentences_from: -- Czy on robi na tobie wrażenie waryata?
Sentences_to: "Did he ever strike you as being crazy--this brother of hers?"
Translated_sentences: -- Does he strike you as a waryata?

Sentences_from: -- Bądź co bądź, wyszłaś pani z tej sprawy obronną ręką -- przekładał jej Holmes. -- Miałaś go pani w swej mocy, a jednak żyjesz.
Sentences_to: "I think that on the whole you have had a fortunate escape," said Sherlock Holmes. "You have had him in your power and he knew it, and yet you are alive.
Translated_sentences: -"Be that as it may, you came out of this case on the defensive," Holmes told her. - You had him in your power, and yet you're alive.

Sentences_from: Studya nad portretami rodzinnymi mogą nas przejąć wiarą w wędrówkę dusz.
Sentences_to: A study of family portraits is enough to convert a man to the doctrine of reincarnation.
Translated_sentences: Studies on family portraits can make us believe in the journey of souls.

Sentences_from: -- Mrs. Lyons -- rzekłem, wstając -- bierze pani na siebie wielką odpowiedzialność i stawia się pani w trudnem położeniu.
Sentences_to: "Mrs. Lyons," said I, as I rose from this long and inconclusive interview, "you are taking a very great responsibility and putting yourself in a very false position by not making an absolutely clean breast of all that you know.
Translated_sentences: -- Mrs. Lyons, "I said, standing up," you are taking on a great responsibility and putting yourself in a difficult position.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli potrafię wydobyć z niego więcej faktów, oszczędzi mi to czasu i trudu.
Sentences_to: But incredulity and indifference were evidently my strongest cards.
Translated_sentences: If I can get more facts out of him, it'll save me time and trouble.

Sentences_from: -- Oby wszystkie przykrości zostały równie szybko usunięte -- życzył mu Sherlock Holmes.
Sentences_to: "May all our difficulties vanish as easily!" said Sherlock Holmes.
Translated_sentences: -"May all grievances be removed as soon as possible," Sherlock Holmes wished him.

Sentences_from: -- Naturalnie, pisywałam do niego, aby mu podziękować za jego delikatność i wspaniałomyślność.
Sentences_to: "I certainly wrote to him once or twice to acknowledge his delicacy and his generosity."
Translated_sentences: -- Naturally, I wrote to him to thank him for his kindness and generosity.

Sentences_from: Pociąganoby pana do odpowiedzialności za to, że, znając kryjówkę zbiegłego więźnia, nie uwiadomiłeś o niej policyi...
Sentences_to: I am not sure that as a conscientious detective my first duty is not to arrest the whole household.
Translated_sentences: You would be held responsible for not notifying the police of an escaped prisoner's hiding place...

Sentences_from: -- Nie, jaśnie panie, tego nie wiem.
Sentences_to: "No, sir, I don't know that."
Translated_sentences: -- No, my lord, I do not know.

Sentences_from: Gdybym zdołał go schwytać, możeby to wyjaśniło wszystkie te zagadki. Całą moją energię wytężę, aby tego celu dopiąć.
Sentences_to: I will say nothing to add to his anxieties, but I will take my own steps to attain my own end.
Translated_sentences: If I could capture him, maybe that would solve all these puzzles. I will use all my energy to achieve this goal.

Sentences_from: Na progu stała pani Barrymore, jeszcze bledsza od męża.
Sentences_to: Her bulky figure in a shawl and skirt might have been comic were it not for the intensity of feeling upon her face.
Translated_sentences: On the threshold stood Mrs. Barrymore, even paler than her husband.

Sentences_from: Zastanowił mnie widok dwóch rosłych chłopów w mundurach żołnierskich; stali, oparci na karabinach i nie spuszczali z nas oka.
Sentences_to: Rolling pasture lands curved upward on either side of us, and old gabled houses peeped out from amid the thick green foliage, but behind the peaceful and sunlit country-side there rose ever, dark against the evening sky, the long, gloomy curve of the moor, broken by the jagged and sinister hills.
Translated_sentences: I was struck by the sight of two large peasants in military uniforms, standing, leaning on their rifles and not taking their eyes off us.

Sentences_from: Lecz na drodze tej miłości istnieją przeszkody. Niedalej, jak dziś, sir Henryk miał przykrą niespodziankę.
Sentences_to: After the conversation which I have quoted about Barrymore, Sir Henry put on his hat and prepared to go out.
Translated_sentences: But there are obstacles in the way of this love. Not long ago, like today, Sir Henry had a nasty surprise.

Sentences_from: Ani słowa przed nim o naszych podejrzeniach... ani słowa! bo inaczej, wszystkie moje plany pójdą w niwecz. Ujrzałem światełko cygara.
Sentences_to: It's the man himself, by all that's wonderful and audacious!
Translated_sentences: Not a word to him about our suspicions... not a word! otherwise, all my plans will go to waste. I saw a cigar light.

Sentences_from: Pani Stapleton zeznaje, iż jej mąż miał w tym względzie kilka projektów: albo upomnieć się o sukcesyę z Ameryki południowej i tam dowieść swej tożsamości i uzyskać fortunę, nie przyjeżdżając do Anglii; albo dostarczyć jakiemu wspólnikowi potrzebnych legitymacyj i za jego pośrednictwem spadek otrzymać; albo prowadzić sam sprawę na miejscu, lecz pod inną postacią zewnętrzną, w takiem przebraniu, żeby nikt poznać go nie mógł.
Sentences_to: "It is a formidable difficulty, and I fear that you ask too much when you expect me to solve it. The past and the present are within the field of my inquiry, but what a man may do in the future is a hard question to answer.
Translated_sentences: Mrs. Stapleton testifies that her husband had several projects in this respect: either to claim success in South America, and there to prove his identity and make his fortune without coming to England; or to furnish to some partner the necessary credentials and receive the inheritance through him; or to conduct the case himself on the spot, but under a different external guise, in such disguise that no one could know him.

Sentences_from: -- To prawda -- przyznał sir Henryk -- a więc Barrymore...
Sentences_to: "That is true," said Sir Henry. "Well, Barrymore --"
Translated_sentences: -'It is true,' admitted Sir Henry, ' and so Barrymore...

Sentences_from: Po chwili milczenia, odebrał mi laskę i przypatrywał jej się gołem okiem.
Sentences_to: "Interesting, though elementary," said he as he returned to his favourite corner of the settee.
Translated_sentences: After a moment of silence, he took my cane and stared at it with his naked eye.

Sentences_from: Nabieram przebiegłości: gdy doktor Mortimer nacierał, chcąc dowiedzieć się, dlaczego interesuję się panią Lyons, napytałem go podstępnie, do jakiego typu należy czaszka pana Frankland; dzięki temu, do końca naszej wycieczki nie słyszałem o niczem innem, tylko o kraniologii.
Sentences_to: I am certainly developing the wisdom of the serpent, for when Mortimer pressed his questions to an inconvenient extent I asked him casually to what type Frankland's skull belonged, and so heard nothing but craniology for the rest of our drive.
Translated_sentences: I am getting crafty: when Dr. Mortimer was trying to find out why I was interested in Mrs. Lyons, I asked him surreptitiously what type of Skull Mr. Frankland belonged to; thus, for the rest of our tour, I heard of nothing but craniology.

Sentences_from: Zresztą za kilka dni opuści te strony.
Sentences_to: I assure you, Sir Henry, that in a very few days the necessary arrangements will have been made and he will be on his way to South America.
Translated_sentences: He'll be leaving these pages in a few days, anyway.

Sentences_from: Ale teraz sir Henryk przekonał się, że to nie był spisek przeciw niemu...
Sentences_to: But now you have heard it, and you will see that if there was a plot it was not against you."
Translated_sentences: But now Sir Henry is convinced that this was not a conspiracy against him...

Sentences_from: Szukajmy wśród najbliższego otoczenia sir Henryka.
Sentences_to: There remain the people who will actually surround Sir Henry Baskerville upon the moor."
Translated_sentences: Let us search among Sir Henry's immediate surroundings.

Sentences_from: -- Jakże się cieszę, że to ty! -- zawołałem, ściskając mu rękę.
Sentences_to: "I never was more glad to see anyone in my life," said I, as I wrung him by the hand.
Translated_sentences: -- I'm so glad it's you! -- I cried, squeezing his hand.

Sentences_from: -- Przypuszczam to samo, co mój przyjaciel.
Sentences_to: "You are quick at identification," said he.
Translated_sentences: -- I'm assuming the same thing as my friend.

Sentences_from: -- Zdaje mi się, że znam tego Johnsona -- rzekł Holmes do portyera. -- Wszak to adwokat: siwy, utyka na nogę.
Sentences_to: "Surely that must be the same Johnson whom I used to know," said Holmes to the porter. "A lawyer, is he not, gray-headed, and walks with a limp?"
Translated_sentences: -"I think I know this Johnson," said Holmes to portyer. -- He's a lawyer, he's grey, he's limping.

Sentences_from: Nazajutrz, przed śniadaniem, poszedłem do pustego pokoju, nawiedzonego przez Barrymora nocy ubiegłej.
Sentences_to: Before breakfast on the morning following my adventure I went down the corridor and examined the room in which Barrymore had been on the night before.
Translated_sentences: The next day, before breakfast, I went to an empty room haunted by Barrymore the night before.

Sentences_from: Nie zwykł wyjawiać swoich planów nikomu, aż do ostatniej chwili.
Sentences_to: Partly it came no doubt from his own masterful nature, which loved to dominate and surprise those who were around him. Partly also from his professional caution, which urged him never to take any chances.
Translated_sentences: He didn't reveal his plans to anyone until the last minute.

Sentences_from: Zostałem odrazu wprowadzony przez schludną pokojówkę do bawialni. Pani Lyons siedziała przy maszynie Remingtona; zerwała się na moje powitanie, lecz ujrzawszy nieznajomego, zmieszała się i spytała, czego sobie życzę.
Sentences_to: A maid showed me in without ceremony, and as I entered the sitting-room a lady, who was sitting before a Remington typewriter, sprang up with a pleasant smile of welcome. Her face fell, however, when she saw that I was a stranger, and she sat down again and asked me the object of my visit.
Translated_sentences: I was suddenly ushered into the playroom by a neat maid. Mrs. Lyons was sitting at Remington's machine; she broke off at my greeting, but when she saw a stranger, she became confused and asked what I wanted.

Sentences_from: Jeszcze jeden dzień, dwa najwyżej, a będę w stanie zmierzyć się z tym łotrem, ale tymczasem strzeż sir Henryka; żałuję nawet, żeś go dziś opuścił.
Sentences_to: Another day--two at the most--and I have my case complete, but until then guard your charge as closely as ever a fond mother watched her ailing child. Your mission to-day has justified itself, and yet I could almost wish that you had not left his side.
Translated_sentences: One more day, two at the most, and I shall be able to face this villain; but in the mean time, guard Sir Henry; I even regret that you have left him this day.

Sentences_from: -- Nie mógłbym jej oznaczyć dokładnie, ale moje wskazówki oddałyby usługę policyi.
Sentences_to: "I may not know exactly where he is, but I am quite sure that I could help the police to lay their hands on him.
Translated_sentences: - I wouldn't be able to tag her exactly, but my tips would put the police service on the line.

Sentences_from: Mówiłem ci już, że twoje raporty dochodziły mnie szybko, odsyłano mi je natychmiast z Baker-Street do Coombe-Tracey.
Sentences_to: "I have already told you that your reports reached me rapidly, being forwarded instantly from Baker Street to Coombe Tracey.
Translated_sentences: I told you, your reports came to me quickly, they were sent straight from Baker Street to Coombe-Tracey.

Sentences_from: Powitał Holmesa z takiem uszanowaniem, jak oficer głównodowodzącego armią.
Sentences_to: I could well remember the scorn which the theories of the reasoner used then to excite in the practical man.
Translated_sentences: He greeted Holmes with the respect of an officer commanding an army.

Sentences_from: Wszak byłeś w tym domu, Watson?
Sentences_to: You have been inside the house, have you not, Watson?
Translated_sentences: You were in this house, weren't you, Watson?

Sentences_from: Mówiłem o tem sir Henrykowi, a on, ze zwykłą sobie szczerością, wezwał Barrymora i zapytał go, czy dostał telegram.
Sentences_to: I told Sir Henry how the matter stood, and he at once, in his downright fashion, had Barrymore up and asked him whether he had received the telegram himself.
Translated_sentences: I told Sir Henry about it, and he, with his usual frankness, called Barrymore and asked him if he had received the Telegram.

Sentences_from: -- O jakich faktach chcesz wiedzieć? -- spytałem.
Sentences_to: "What sort of facts?" I asked.
Translated_sentences: -- What facts do you want to know? -- I asked.

Sentences_from: Wysunęła ręce z rękawów -- były okryte sińcami. -- Ale to najmniejsza -- ciągnęła dalej. -- On zdeptał moją duszę, poniżył ją... Wszystko znosiłam: osamotnienie, poniewierkę, dopóki mogłam wierzyć w jego miłość; ale i tu spotkał mnie zawód... Wybuchła płaczem.
Sentences_to: "Thank God! Thank God! Oh, this villain! See how he has treated me!" She shot her arms out from her sleeves, and we saw with horror that they were all mottled with bruises. "But this is nothing--nothing! It is my mind and soul that he has tortured and defiled. I could endure it all, ill-usage, solitude, a life of deception, everything, as long as I could still cling to the hope that I had his love, but now I know that in this also I have been his dupe and his tool." She broke into passionate sobbing as she spoke.
Translated_sentences: She put her hands out of her sleeves -- they were covered in bruises. -- But it's the smallest -- she kept going. -- He trampled on my soul, humiliated it... I endured everything: loneliness, misery, as long as I could believe in his love; but even here I was disappointed... She burst into tears.

Sentences_from: Młody Baskerville przyglądał się krajobrazowi z widoczną przyjemnością, zwłaszcza, gdyśmy wjechali w jego rodzinne Devonshire.
Sentences_to: In a very few hours the brown earth had become ruddy, the brick had changed to granite, and red cows grazed in well-hedged fields where the lush grasses and more luxuriant vegetation spoke of a richer, if a damper, climate. Young Baskerville stared eagerly out of the window, and cried aloud with delight as he recognized the familiar features of the Devon scenery.
Translated_sentences: Young Baskerville looked at the landscape with apparent pleasure, especially as we drove into his native Devonshire.

Sentences_from: Tymczasem sir Henryk i jego towarzyszka stanęli na ścieżce.
Sentences_to: Our friend, Sir Henry, and the lady had halted on the path and were standing deeply absorbed in their conversation, when I was suddenly aware that I was not the only witness of their interview. A wisp of green floating in the air caught my eye, and another glance showed me that it was carried on a stick by a man who was moving among the broken ground.
Translated_sentences: Meanwhile, Sir Henry and his companion stood in the path.

Sentences_from: -- Sir Karol otrzymał list tego dnia rano.
Sentences_to: "Well, Sir Henry, your uncle had a letter that morning.
Translated_sentences: - Sir Charles received a letter this morning.

Sentences_from: Gdyśmy weszli na pierwsze piętro, naprzeciw nam wybiegł sir Henryk, widocznie wzburzony. W ręku trzymał stary but.
Sentences_to: So furious was he that he was hardly articulate, and when he did speak it was in a much broader and more Western dialect than any which we had heard from him in the morning.
Translated_sentences: As we entered the first floor, Sir Henry came running towards us, visibly agitated. He was holding an old shoe.

Sentences_from: -- Sir Karol był tak zdenerwowany, że ukazanie się psa mogło go zabić.
Sentences_to: "His nerves were so worked up that the appearance of any dog might have had a fatal effect upon his diseased heart.
Translated_sentences: - Sir Charles was so upset that the appearance of a dog could have killed him.

Sentences_from: Teraz jednak żałuję, że nie przyjąłem zaprosin Stapletona, który do mnie pisał nad wieczorem. Gdybym był poszedł, spędziłbym wieczór weselej.
Sentences_to: If I hadn't sworn not to go about alone I might have had a more lively evening, for I had a message from Stapleton asking me over there."
Translated_sentences: Now, however, I regret that I did not accept the invitation Stapleton, who wrote to me over the evening. If I'd gone, I'd have had a happier night.

Sentences_from: Holmes zerwał się na nogi, wybiegł przed jaskinię, nastawił ucha.
Sentences_to: Holmes had sprung to his feet, and I saw his dark, athletic outline at the door of the hut, his shoulders stooping, his head thrust forward, his face peering into the darkness.
Translated_sentences: Holmes got to his feet, ran out in front of the cave, set his ear.

Sentences_from: -- Tak, na wszelki przypadek wziąłem rewolwer.
Sentences_to: "Yes, I thought it as well to take them."
Translated_sentences: -- Yeah, I brought a revolver just in case.

Sentences_from: -- Jakto? Nie chce pan zostać na obiad?
Sentences_to: "Surely you will stay and have some dinner?"
Translated_sentences: -- How so? Don't you want to stay for dinner?

Sentences_from: Ujrzałem coś zielonego, zawieszonego w powietrzu.
Sentences_to: His arm was round her, but it seemed to me that she was straining away from him with her face averted. He stooped his head to hers, and she raised one hand as if in protest.
Translated_sentences: I saw something green suspended in the air.

Sentences_from: Przytoczę kilka ustępów, zaczynając od dnia, następującego po naszym pościgu.
Sentences_to: I proceed, then, from the morning which followed our abortive chase of the convict and our other strange experiences upon the moor.
Translated_sentences: I will quote a few paragraphs, starting with the day following our pursuit.

Sentences_from: Była to zwykła, szara koperta; adres: _Sir Henryk Baskerville_, _Northumberland Hotel_ -- wypisany był drukiem, stempel Charing Cross i data na kopercie z poprzedniego wieczora.
Sentences_to: It was of common quality, grayish in colour. The address, "Sir Henry Baskerville, Northumberland Hotel," was printed in rough characters; the postmark "Charing Cross," and the date of posting the preceding evening.
Translated_sentences: It was a plain grey envelope; the address, Sir Henry Baskerville, Northumberland Hotel, was printed, with a Charing Cross stamp and the date on the envelope from the previous evening.

Sentences_from: Dużo jest domków odludnych na łące i trzęsawisku, choćby naprzykład willa pana Stapleton: stoi na uboczu.
Sentences_to: There are lonely houses scattered over the moor, and he is a fellow who would stick at nothing. You only want to get a glimpse of his face to see that.
Translated_sentences: There are a lot of secluded cottages on the meadow and the moor, for example, Mr. Stapleton's villa: it stands on the sidelines.

Sentences_from: Był to człowiek dzielny, rozumny, praktyczny i tak samo, jak ja, nie podlegający złudzeniom wyobraźni.
Sentences_to: He was a strong-minded man, sir, shrewd, practical, and as unimaginative as I am myself.
Translated_sentences: He was a brave man, intelligent, practical and, like me, not subject to the illusions of the imagination.

Sentences_from: To może być... tak, to jest pinczer.
Sentences_to: It may have been--yes, by Jove, it is a curly-haired spaniel."
Translated_sentences: It could be... yes, this is pinscher.

Sentences_from: Pan Sherlock Holmes zwykł był wstawać późno, o ile nie czuwał przez całą noc, a zdarzało mu się to nieraz.
Sentences_to: Mr. Sherlock Holmes, who was usually very late in the mornings, save upon those not infrequent occasions when he was up all night, was seated at the breakfast table.
Translated_sentences: Mr. Sherlock Holmes was in the habit of getting up late, unless he was awake all night, and this happened to him on several occasions.

Sentences_from: -- A więc można ją łatwo przesadzić?
Sentences_to: "Then anyone could have got over it?"
Translated_sentences: -- So it can be easily exaggerated?

Sentences_from: Istotnie dostrzegłem coś szamocącego się; po chwili wysunęła się długa szyja i rozległ się okrzyk przeraźliwy. Drgnąłem.
Sentences_to: Something brown was rolling and tossing among the green sedges. Then a long, agonized, writhing neck shot upward and a dreadful cry echoed over the moor.
Translated_sentences: Indeed, I saw something struggling; after a moment a long neck was stretched out and a tremendous cry was uttered. I was trembling.

Sentences_from: Roześmiałem się niedowierzająco. Holmes zasiadł wygodnie w fotelu i puszczał kłęby dymu.
Sentences_to: I laughed incredulously as Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee and blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling.
Translated_sentences: I laughed in disbelief. Holmes sat comfortably in his chair and puffed smoke.

Sentences_from: -- Teraz ja udzielę ci garstkę informacyj wzamian za te, których ty mi dostarczyłeś.
Sentences_to: "I am giving you some information now, in return for all that you have given me.
Translated_sentences: -- Now I'm gonna give you a handful of information in exchange for the ones you gave me.

Sentences_from: Całe dzieło, zapoczątkowane przez sir Karola, pójdzie w niwecz, jeśli nikt nie zamieszka na zamku.
Sentences_to: All the good work which has been done by Sir Charles will crash to the ground if there is no tenant of the Hall.
Translated_sentences: All the work that Sir Charles has begun will go to waste if no one lives in the castle.

Sentences_from: Wyobrażałam sobie, że on działa dla mnie -- teraz widzę, że byłam tylko narzędziem w jego ręku.
Sentences_to: I imagined that all was for my own sake. But now I see that I was never anything but a tool in his hands.
Translated_sentences: I imagined that he was working for me -- now I see that I was just a tool in his hand.

Sentences_from: -- Nie wiedziałem, kim jesteś, ale poprzysiągłem sobie wykryć tajemnicę.
Sentences_to: "I did not know who you were, but I was determined to find out."
Translated_sentences: - I didn't know who you were, but I swore to myself to find out the secret.

Sentences_from: Byłem ciekawy, czy i teraz rozlegały się podobne dźwięki...
Sentences_to: I was wondering if there were any evidence of such a sound to-night."
Translated_sentences: I wondered if there were similar sounds now...

Sentences_from: -- Powiadam ci, że stamtąd, Watson. A ty jak sądzisz?
Sentences_to: "It rose and fell with the wind.
Translated_sentences: -- I'm telling you, Watson. What do you think?

Sentences_from: Sprawa istotnie bardzo skomplikowana, dużo w niej punktów ciemnych, ale spodziewam się rzucić na nie światło,
Sentences_to: It has been an exceedingly difficult and most complicated business. There are several points upon which we still want light--but it is coming all the same."
Translated_sentences: The matter is indeed very complicated, there are many dark points in it, but I expect to shed light on them,

Sentences_from: Sam Holmes powiadał, że nigdy jeszcze nie zdarzyła mu się sprawa tak zawiła.
Sentences_to: "You will, I am sure, excuse my presumption, Dr. Watson," said he, as he came panting up to where I stood.
Translated_sentences: Holmes himself said he had never had a case so complicated.

Sentences_from: Na ulicy zobaczyliśmy sir Henryka i doktora Mortimer o paręset metrów przed sobą. Szli w kierunku Oxford street.
Sentences_to: Dr. Mortimer and Baskerville were still visible about two hundred yards ahead of us in the direction of Oxford Street.
Translated_sentences: In the street we saw Sir Henry and Dr Mortimer a few hundred yards ahead of us. They were walking in the direction of Oxford Street.

Sentences_from: Wybiegł z pokoju w szlafroku; w minutę potem ukazał się w surducie.
Sentences_to: He rushed into his room in his dressing-gown and was back again in a few seconds in a frock-coat.
Translated_sentences: He ran out of the room in a dressing gown; a minute later he appeared in surduta.

Sentences_from: Kamienne siedziby naszych przodków zasiewają gęsto oparzelisko, i dziwić się należy, dlaczego oni osiedlali się w tych bagnach?
Sentences_to: As you look at their gray stone huts against the scarred hill-sides you leave your own age behind you, and if you were to see a skin-clad, hairy man crawl out from the low door fitting a flint-tipped arrow on to the string of his bow, you would feel that his presence there was more natural than your own.
Translated_sentences: The stone houses of our ancestors sowed thick burns, and one wonders why they settled in these swamps?

Sentences_from: Wiedział, gdzie mieszkam, w jakim interesie sir Henryk przybył do mnie; poznał mnie na Regent-Street; domyślił się, że spostrzegłem numer dorożkarza, że go sprowadzę, i dlatego wymienił moje nazwisko. Powiadam ci, Watson, mamy przeciwnika nielada.
Sentences_to: "The cunning rascal! He knew our number, knew that Sir Henry Baskerville had consulted me, spotted who I was in Regent Street, conjectured that I had got the number of the cab and would lay my hands on the driver, and so sent back this audacious message.
Translated_sentences: He knew where I lived, on what business Sir Henry came to see me; he met me in Regent Street; he guessed that I had seen the carriage-driver's number, that I was going to bring him, and therefore he mentioned my name. I'm telling you, Watson, we have nielad's opponent.

Sentences_from: W chwili, gdyś mnie odnalazł na moczarach, miałem już w ręku wszystkie nici spisku, lecz nie posiadałem materyału dowodowego, z którym mógłbym stanąć przed sądem.
Sentences_to: This also you cleared up in a very effective way, though I had already come to the same conclusions from my own observations.
Translated_sentences: By the time you found me in the swamp, I already had all the threads of the conspiracy in my hand, but I did not have the material evidence with which to stand before the court.

Sentences_from: -- Przepraszam cię -- rzekłem. -- Czy mógłbyś mi wyjaśnić, kto żywił psa podczas pobytu Stapletona w Londynie?
Sentences_to: "One moment!" said I. "You have, no doubt, described the sequence of events correctly, but there is one point which you have left unexplained. What became of the hound when its master was in London?"
Translated_sentences: -- I'm sorry, I said. -- Could you tell me who fed the dog while Stapleton was in London?

Sentences_from: Powiedz mi otwarcie: co ci się nie podoba?
Sentences_to: I have come here with no object except to help him. Tell me, frankly, what it is that you don't like."
Translated_sentences: Tell me frankly: what do you not like?

Sentences_from: Wreszcie Stapleton skinął na siostrę, która po chwili wahania poszła za nim, rzuciwszy spojrzenie baronetowi.
Sentences_to: "Halloa, Watson! Where have you dropped from?" said he. "You don't mean to say that you came after me in spite of all?"
Translated_sentences: At last Stapleton beckoned to his sister, who, after a moment's hesitation, followed him, casting a glance at the baronet.

Sentences_from: -- Więc chcecie mnie opuścić? -- powtórzył sir Henryk. -- Wszak twoja rodzina służyła mojej przez kilka pokoleń. Przykroby mi było rozpoczynać nowe życie od zrywania tak dawnego stosunku.
Sentences_to: "Only when it is quite convenient to you, sir."
Translated_sentences: -- So you want to leave me? - Sir Henry repeated. - After all, your family has served mine for generations. It was a shame for me to start a new life by breaking up such an old relationship.

Sentences_from: Rumieniec znikł z jej twarzy, w jednej chwili zbladła śmiertelnie.
Sentences_to: The flush had faded in an instant, and a deathly face was before me.
Translated_sentences: The blush disappeared from her face, in an instant she turned deadly pale.

Sentences_from: On ma w oczach groźne błyski, a zacięte usta zdradzają naturę twardą i nieubłaganą.
Sentences_to: There is a dry glitter in his eyes, and a firm set of his thin lips, which goes with a positive and possibly a harsh nature.
Translated_sentences: He has a menacing twinkle in his eyes, and a fierce mouth betrays a hard and unforgiving nature.

Sentences_from: Wśród zielska i trawy wyzierał jakiś czarny przedmiot.
Sentences_to: Once only we saw a trace that someone had passed that perilous way before us.
Translated_sentences: There was a black object lurking among the weeds and grass.

Sentences_from: Treść drugiej depeszy była następująca: „Zwiedziłem dwadzieścia trzy hotele wskazane, ale nie mogłem znaleźć owego _Timesa_.
Sentences_to: "Visited twenty-three hotels as directed, but sorry, to report unable to trace cut sheet of Times.--CARTWRIGHT."
Translated_sentences: The content of the second message was as follows: "I visited twenty-three hotels indicated, but I could not find this _times_.

Sentences_from: -- Nie. Przyszliśmy tutaj, aby schwytać mordercę i nie cofniemy się w pół drogi.
Sentences_to: "No, by thunder; we have come out to get our man, and we will do it. We after the convict, and a hell-hound, as likely as not, after us.
Translated_sentences: -- No. We came here to catch a killer, and we're not going back half way.

Sentences_from: Serdeczne słowa Holmesa rozproszyły mój żal do niego, tembardziej, iż czułem, że lepiej się stało, żem nie wiedział o jego przebywaniu na bagnie.
Sentences_to: I was still rather raw over the deception which had been practised upon me, but the warmth of Holmes's praise drove my anger from my mind. I felt also in my heart that he was right in what he said and that it was really best for our purpose that I should not have known that he was upon the moor.
Translated_sentences: Holmes ' kind words dissipated my pity for him, especially as I felt that it was better that I had not known of his presence in the swamp.

Sentences_from: Nie namyślając się, wszedł do pokoju.
Sentences_to: He walked into the room, and as he did so Barrymore sprang up from the window with a sharp hiss of his breath and stood, livid and trembling, before us.
Translated_sentences: Without thinking, he entered the room.

Sentences_from: Pochlebiam sobie, że każda piędź ziemi jest mi teraz dobrze znana.
Sentences_to: He is not a man with intimate friends. Where, then, could he have been?
Translated_sentences: I flatter myself that every inch of the earth is now well known to me.

Sentences_from: Należy przedewszystkiem rozstrzygnąć dwa zagadnienia: popierwsze, czy zaszła zbrodnia? Powtóre: w jaki sposób ją spełniono?
Sentences_to: There are two questions waiting for us at the outset. The one is whether any crime has been committed at all; the second is, what is the crime and how was it committed?
Translated_sentences: First of all, there are two issues to be resolved: has there been a crime or has there been a crime? Again: how was it fulfilled?

Sentences_from: Do tego słupa uwiązana była postać ludzka; w pierwszej chwili nie mogliśmy poznać: czy to mężczyzna, czy kobieta.
Sentences_to: To this post a figure was tied, so swathed and muffled in the sheets which had been used to secure it that one could not for the moment tell whether it was that of a man or a woman.
Translated_sentences: A human figure was tied to this pole; at first we could not tell whether it was a man or a woman.

Sentences_from: -- Wiem, dlaczego był przy furtce o tej godzinie.
Sentences_to: "I know why he was at the gate at that hour.
Translated_sentences: - I know why he was at the gate at this hour.

Sentences_from: Płonęło ono niewątpliwie w domu Stapletona.
Sentences_to: It could only come from the lonely abode of the Stapletons.
Translated_sentences: It was burning, no doubt, in Stapleton's house.

Sentences_from: Nie ułożyliśmy planu kampanii, ale baronet uważa prostą drogę za najkrótszą i najwłaściwszą.
Sentences_to: We had arranged no plan of campaign, but the baronet is a man to whom the most direct way is always the most natural.
Translated_sentences: We haven't laid out a campaign plan, but the baronet thinks the straight road is the shortest and most appropriate.

Sentences_from: -- Musisz się wymówić. On pójdzie sam.
Sentences_to: "Then you must excuse yourself and he must go alone.
Translated_sentences: -- You have to say something. He'll go alone.

Sentences_from: Ten człowiek chłodny, nieprzenikniony, do którego od pierwszej chwili wstręt uczułem, wydawał mi się teraz potworem o słodkim uśmiechu.
Sentences_to: In that impassive, colourless man, with his straw hat and his butterfly-net, I seemed to see something terrible--a creature of infinite patience and craft, with a smiling face and a murderous heart.
Translated_sentences: This cold, impenetrable man, for whom I had been disgusted from the first moment, seemed to me now a monster with a sweet smile.

Sentences_from: Wiatr niósł go wśród nocnej ciszy; z początku było to ciche warczenie, niebawem przeszło w straszne wycie.
Sentences_to: It came with the wind through the silence of the night, a long, deep mutter, then a rising howl, and then the sad moan in which it died away. Again and again it sounded, the whole air throbbing with it, strident, wild, and menacing.
Translated_sentences: The wind carried him through the stillness of the night; at first it was a low growl, soon it turned into a terrible howl.

Sentences_from: Dokoła nie było widać żadnego żywego stworzenia.
Sentences_to: I looked round, with a chill of fear in my heart, at the huge swelling plain, mottled with the green patches of rushes. Nothing stirred over the vast expanse save a pair of ravens, which croaked loudly from a tor behind us.
Translated_sentences: There wasn't a living thing in sight.

Sentences_from: -- Nie potrafię pana objaśnić w tym względzie.
Sentences_to: "I am afraid that I cannot answer that question."
Translated_sentences: -- I can't explain it to you.

Sentences_from: -- To bardzo ważny szczegół -- poświadczył. -- Wypełnia lukę, której nie zdołałem pokryć.
Sentences_to: "This is most important," said he when I had concluded. "It fills up a gap which I had been unable to bridge, in this most complex affair.
Translated_sentences: -- This is a very important detail -- he testified. -- It fills a gap I couldn't close.

Sentences_from: -- Nędznik!... -- zawołał Holmes z oburzeniem. -- Dawaj no tu flaszkę z wódką -- rzekł do Lestrada. -- Trzeba ją posadzić na krześle i rozcierać.
Sentences_to: "The brute!" cried Holmes. "Here, Lestrade, your brandy-bottle! Put her in the chair! She has fainted from ill-usage and exhaustion."
Translated_sentences: -- Wretch!... - Holmes exclaimed indignantly. -"Give me a bottle of vodka," he said to Lestrada. -- You have to put her in a chair and rub her.

Sentences_from: -- Oto twoje sprawozdania -- rzekł. -- Dostawałem je z 24 godzinnem opóźnieniem i oddały mi znaczne usługi.
Sentences_to: "Here are your reports, my dear fellow, and very well thumbed, I assure you. I made excellent arrangements, and they are only delayed one day upon their way.
Translated_sentences: -"Here are your reports," he said. -- I got them 24 hours late, and they gave me a lot of service.

Sentences_from: Przysięgam panu, iż pisząc ten list, nie wiedziałam, że narażam na niebezpieczeństwo sir Karola, który był dla mnie lepszym od rodzonego ojca.
Sentences_to: One thing I swear to you, and that is that when I wrote the letter I never dreamed of any harm to the old gentleman, who had been my kindest friend."
Translated_sentences: I swear to you, when I wrote this letter, I did not know that I was endangering Sir Charles, who was better to me than my father.

Sentences_from: -- Mam nadzieję, że wyjaśnienie mojego przyjaciela zostanie uznane jako jedynie możliwe.
Sentences_to: "Yes, indeed. I have no doubt that my friend's explanation will cover the facts.
Translated_sentences: -- I hope that my friend's explanation will be considered only possible.

Sentences_from: Rzucił się naprzód, ja za nim.
Sentences_to: He had started running swiftly over the moor, and I had followed at his heels.
Translated_sentences: He lunged forward, I followed.

Sentences_from: -- Powiem panu szczerze: przewiduję nowe nieszczęście...
Sentences_to: "Look at Sir Charles's death! That was bad enough, for all that the coroner said.
Translated_sentences: -- I'll tell you frankly: I foresee a new misfortune...

Sentences_from: -- Skręcił kark, spadając z tej skały.
Sentences_to: "He appears to have broken his neck by falling over these rocks.
Translated_sentences: -- He broke his neck falling off that rock.

Sentences_from: Chwilami zdawało nam się, że jest blizkiem, to znów że bardzo odległem.
Sentences_to: There is nothing so deceptive as the distance of a light upon a pitch-dark night, and sometimes the glimmer seemed to be far away upon the horizon and sometimes it might have been within a few yards of us.
Translated_sentences: At times it seemed to us that he was close, then again that I was very far away.

Sentences_from: Żyzna okolica pozostała za nami; mieliśmy przed sobą ziemię szarą, jałową, zrzadka ukazywała się ludzka siedziba, opasana murem z kamieni. Wreszcie wjechaliśmy w jar głęboki; roztoczyła się znowu zieleń drzew, a w oddali ukazały się dwie strzeliste wieże. Stangret wskazał biczem.
Sentences_to: We had left the fertile country behind and beneath us. We looked back on it now, the slanting rays of a low sun turning the streams to threads of gold and glowing on the red earth new turned by the plough and the broad tangle of the woodlands. The road in front of us grew bleaker and wilder over huge russet and olive slopes, sprinkled with giant boulders. Now and then we passed a moorland cottage, walled and roofed with stone, with no creeper to break its harsh outline. Suddenly we looked down into a cup-like depression, patched with stunted oaks and firs which had been twisted and bent by the fury of years of storm. Two high, narrow towers rose over the trees. The driver pointed with his whip.
Translated_sentences: The fertile region remained behind us; we had before us a gray, barren land, a human habitation, girded with a wall of stones, appeared red-haired. At last we entered a deep spring; the green of the trees spread out again, and in the distance two shooting towers appeared. Stangret pointed with his whip.

Sentences_from: Więc znowu jedna zagadka powiększyła szereg drobnych tajemnic, następujących tak szybko po sobie.
Sentences_to: The German was sent for but professed to know nothing of the matter, nor could any inquiry clear it up.
Translated_sentences: So once again, one mystery has added to a series of minor mysteries that have followed so quickly.

Sentences_from: Zwiodłem wszystkich, nie wyłączając ciebie, i zjawiłem się potajemnie, wówczas, gdy sądziliście wszyscy, że bawię w Londynie.
Sentences_to: I deceived everybody, therefore, yourself included, and I came down secretly when I was supposed to be in London.
Translated_sentences: I deceived everyone, not excepting you, and I came secretly when you all thought I was playing in London.

Sentences_from: -- Wszelkie wątpliwości rozprasza fakt, że słowa zostały wycięte w całości, nie zaś pojedynczemi literami, a nawet widzimy dwa słowa wycięte razem: _dbasz o_...
Sentences_to: "If any possible doubt remained it is settled by the fact that 'keep away' and 'from the' are cut out in one piece."
Translated_sentences: -- All doubts are dispelled by the fact that the words were cut out in full, not in single letters, and we even see two words cut together: _dbasz o_...

Sentences_from: -- To zapewne potwierdzenie jakiejś legendy -- wtrącił Holmes.
Sentences_to: "It appears to be a statement of some sort."
Translated_sentences: -"It's probably a legend," Holmes interjected.

Sentences_from: Jest to jedna ze wskazówek, która mi pomogła do określenia daty.
Sentences_to: It is one of several indications which enabled me to fix the date."
Translated_sentences: This is one of the tips that helped me to determine the date.

Sentences_from: Najlepiej Seldonowi twarz zakryć, a zwłoki będą bezpieczne do jutra rana.
Sentences_to: I think that if we put something over his face he will be safe until morning."
Translated_sentences: It's best to cover Seldon's face, and the body will be safe by tomorrow morning.

Sentences_from: „Wkrótce potem, Hugon, zostawiwszy swoich kompanów przy butelkach i kartach, podążył do swojej ofiary, a widząc, że ptaszek opuścił klatkę, jak szalony powrócił do komnaty biesiadnej, wytłukł szkło i wśród okropnych przekleństw i złorzeczeń zaprzysiągł, że odda ciało i duszę dyabłu, jeśli ten dopomoże mu odzyskać dziewczynę.
Sentences_to: "It chanced that some little time later Hugo left his guests to carry food and drink--with other worse things, perchance--to his captive, and so found the cage empty and the bird escaped. Then, as it would seem, he became as one that hath a devil, for, rushing down the stairs into the dining-hall, he sprang upon the great table, flagons and trenchers flying before him, and he cried aloud before all the company that he would that very night render his body and soul to the Powers of Evil if he might but overtake the wench.
Translated_sentences: "Soon after, Hugon, leaving his companions by the bottles and cards, went to his victim, and seeing that the bird had left the cage, he returned like a madman to the mourning chamber, broke the glass, and, amid terrible curses and curses, swore that he would give up the body and soul of the devil, if he would help him to recover the girl.

It is my experience that it is only an amiable man in this world who receives testimonials, only an unambitious one who abandons a London career for the country, and only an absent-minded one who leaves his stick and not his visiting-card after waiting an hour in your room."
